reviewText:
I think Creeper World 3 catches a lot of people off guard because of the cheap price, low resolution graphics and understated appeal. It also gets called a Tower Defense game a lot, which does the unique strategic components a horrible injustice. Instead, Arc Eternal is a laid-back thinking mans' RTS with unprecedented play-more value and excels as a game you can sink some time into in the form of a well thought out and strictly controlled approach, or as a casual attack on a map every now and then. It's like Civilization V in the respect that you'll launch it for a quick 20 minute game and find yourself embroiled in the relentless depths of an alien planet fighting to make a foothold on a section of map on the 4th planet of your 3rd star system 6 hours later, wondering where the time went.

The amount of content in here is staggering, and the campaign provides such a good learning curve and introduction to the new structures and some possible strategies that can't be praised enough. There's also an engaging backstory in the main campaigns which help you feel isolated and alone while fighting the uncaring, unforgiving creep, and while the dialogue is cliche at times, it helps bolster the already engaging gameplay and add a little depth.

Highlights
The best part of this game is simply the gameplay. While the tower defense mechanics have been done to death and don't offer anything particularly insightful, the different natures of the two opposing forces here make for a level of adaptable strategy that you wont see in many games. The structures are all balanced and simple but effective additions like Terraforming and one-use items make for even more ways to play and even more things to spend time working on.

The sheer amount of content is the other great part of this world, and deserves praise.

* The first port of call is the Arc Eternal which acts as the campaign mode and teaches the player the basics and structures, and consists of 9 star systems for a total of approximately 50 levels.
* There's the Alpha Sector which includes many early maps and a ton made by the alpha and beta players.
* The Prospectors Zone features procedurally generated maps.
* There's Tormented Space for those seeking challenge which includes maps from hard to literally impossible.
* The Dial Map Device acts as a map generation tool and lets you play more specific maps.

Mistakes & Annoyances
For many, the simple enemy A.I. is an issue here, and it can be argued that the very flat nature of the enemy intelligence makes for a somewhat bland approach. I'd counterargue and say that this game is more about finding solutions you like, and/or finding the optimal or most efficient route to victory and that the focus doesn't need to be on the creep.

* The difficulty curve isn't very smooth, and you can find yourself struggling way beyond what you'd expect in some of the later campaign missions, or struggling to overcome frustrating maps. There are also several outright impossible missions which nobody has yet been able to find a solution to.

Recommendations
Arc Eternal comes priced at £10.99/14.99€/$14.99 and while it contains a huge amount of play time, including a main story of at least 15 hours, it's still probably slightly overpriced for most players when compared against competitors. It's one of those games which you'll either love or hate, and so playing the demos listed below, or the flash versions of the developers other titles before making a full priced purchase is recommended.

* If the huge amount of content included by default wasn't enough for you, there are a ton of user maps too with different types of play. There are even Play as Creeper style maps.
* Some of the earlier titles are also available for free play in Flash on Kongregate[www.kongregate.com].
* There are demos of all 3 of the Creeper World games available on KnuckleCrackers' website which are much shorter.

reviewText:
Damn. This. Game.

Avoid it all costs. There is a good chance, if you were born before the 90s,
or even after, have a history of strategy games addiction and are suffering
from the almost always fatal 'just one more turn' syndrome; well, this game
may eat your soul. That what is left. As for it being real time, you'll just be
advancing your defenses one tiny bit more, just getting that one upgrade,
maybe, yeah, well, that strategic position and then, then call it a day.

You know what? From that position, the other two, just saying, be a matter
of minutes, at most. Well, that was fast, I might just set up initial positions
on the next planet, for tomorrow. Huh, when I set the alarm clock I still had
eight hours to sleep, now there are only five left? Damn it! I'm not going to
school anymore!

I won't talk about the gameplay. Things are already worse as they are now.
Don't let yourself get fooled by it's uniqueness, the well balanced challenges,
the well worked out story line or even the insane replayability.

You've still got the chance at a life! Don't waste it! I almost escaped.
But I did reinstall Creeper World. And I will be in Arc. Eternal.

reviewText: Creeper World 3 is a very innovative strategy/TD game which resolves around fighting a very unique enemy using a variety of weapons, including a 4-6 hours story, two entire galaxies to conquer, random map generator and tons of insane custom maps (most of which powered by practically limitless custom programming language). If you're a story kind of person then I recommend starting from the first title to understand it all.

reviewText:
Playing TD's as a youngun, who recently discovered the wonders of the internet, were absolutely incredible times. But I always got a bit tired of the repetative movement of putting down another tower, upgrading them blah blah blah.... and then just leaving the game to run it's course, throwing wave after wave of enemies until your computer began to stutter and lag behind as it was somehow managing to cope with an incredible array of pixals being thrown into your eyeballs. I am mainly talking about the infamous Bloons TD, which will always remain my favourite TD, although there are others. However, this game is a little different in that respect.

I like to think of it as a combination of a TD and RTS, in the sense that The Creeper, some blue liquid thing, is not stuck on rails and just has to get from A to B as it floats down a path ignoring all defences on its journey, it is instead open to go where it pleases, only limited by the geography of the landscape. The RTS element in the game is the fact that you build up cannons to protect your 'base' and resource collectors. They take time to build and must be placed strategically in order to maximise the efficiency of your defence and keep The Creeper at bay. After that, you must push forward and move your defences forward even more. But they can get delinked from getting resources, so extenders are put in place. On large maps, it can be very rewarding seeing a huge web of links and seeing your packages of Anti-Creeper and firepower flowing down these pathways.

In later missions, more enemies arise and give even more things to think about when planning out defences, but don't worry. A reasonably nice variety in defence types can help with that. But you'll have to play it in order to find out what.

reviewText:
***Written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposes***

Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is a unique tower defense game/RTS that is more tower offense than defense, something I haven't seen before. You are a captain of a ship who has just woken up after a very very long time in cryo sleep and in the time you have been gone humanity has vanished as all the civilasations that once were have been wiped out by the creeper, a strange organism which destroys everything it touches. At the time of writing this review I have only put in three hours and have barely scratched the surface but as you can see from other reviewers' play time there is a lot to this game and a lot of replayability.

+Nice pixel graphics
+Simple UI and great controls
+A very interesting story
+Interesting concept, instead of building towers in the path of an oncoming enemy you create networks of towers and take the fight to the enemy. There are small enemy towers which emitt the creepers which gradually spread across the map, using towers you have to beat back the creepers until your network of towers is close enough to use a special offensive tower which destroys the emitter. The gameplay is quite hard to explain and I probably haven't done it justice so it's best to watch some gameplay videos.
+Your towers can be moved as the creepers are beaten back out of range of your towers
+It's challenging without feeling too difficult or unfair
+The mission menu is an interactive starmap and you get to see your ship travel from one planet or star system to another
+Nice soundtrack
+Can be paused at any point during a mission
+You can create and share your own levels

-Either some people are god-like at this game or the leaderboards have been cheated
-If you make any mistakes with what you build early on in a mission it usually ruins your chances of winning, for example if you don't build enough reactors at the start and you run low on energy later in the game you will most likely be destroyed. It adds another layer of difficulty but it can be pretty annoying

Verdict:
9

An absolutely brilliant game that is more like an RTS than a TD with an impressively good story, a must buy for fans of either genre.

El K.

reviewText: This is not a traditional tower defense game.  You don't build mazes.  You don't upgrade towers.  There are no units to attack.  Yet, it contains a lot of the same mechanics as TD games:  you build towers which attack for you;  you decide whether to spend or invest resources; you strategically place towers at the right places and times.  Thus, I don't feel uncomfortable categorizing this in the Tower Defense genre.\n\nThe game goes like this:  you expand your base to earn resources.  The larger the surface-area of your base, the more resources-per-second you earn.  Meanwhile, the enemy" is simply a geyser of fluid (called "creeper") which spreads out in all directions.  If the fluid touches a tower

recommended: so you can get close enough to destroy the geyser(s).\n\nOn paper

reviewText: There's hundreds of hours of strategy madness in this thing. The ~40 hour campaign is just the tip of the iceberg. There's also a random level generator (with parameters and user ratings), a level editor with online sharing, all sorts of weird alpha levels, a mashup with Gauntlet in the credits screen(!), and two other flavours of endless levels that I haven't bothered clicking on yet.\n\nRight, the game. It's a bit tower defence, a bit RTS, and a bit of logistics / network optimisation... because your base is a router. The villain is a fluid (a refreshing change from zombies), and you can terraform the map to direct your liquid foe into reservoirs for ease of blasting. Just look at the screenshots and you'll know right away if it's your thing or not.

reviewText:
What a great game! I've put quite a few hours into it. For those of you put off by the fairly simplistic graphics, don't be! It's the gameplay which is the real selling point of this game.

For those of you on the fence, imagine attempting to fight a tidal wave. With guns. And mortars. And another tidal wave of your own. And sometimes really big guns. The Creeper is a living liquid that makes Tiberium look like a small chemical spill. It's coming for you from all sides and directions. It cares not for the small base you've built, only for consuming everything.

So dig in. In some levels you'll have to do this quite literally, as terraforming is a tool at your disposal. In some levels you'll be hanging on by a thread, almost consumed the second your power goes down to build that reactor you need to expand. In other levels, you will actively hate the liquid that is all set to consume everything you've worked so hard to create.

But you will love every second of this game.

A really unique concept which will keep you entertained for hours on end. Gets a 9.5/10 from me!


One more thing! As mentioned to me in the comments, there is a demo version of the game on Kongregate. Check it out if you're still undecided!

reviewText:
Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal
I think that Creeper World 3; Arc Eternal may be one of the greatest games that currently exist. I will add a TL;DR at the end.

Gameplay
Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is a perfect mix of RTS and Tower Defense along with aspects of slight management. You fight against a liquid like and versatile foe known as Creeper. This game has infinite, and I do mean nearly infinite replayability. Once you finish the base story you can go and do thousands of more missions created by the creators and the community. This is the best strategy game I have ever played. There is not much in this world like being completely surrounded by Creeper and slowly, ever so slowly pushing back and destroying every last piece of it. There are tons of ways to beat levels whether you want to attack swiftly with risk or play for a longer game to build your layout to counteract the ever attacking foe. You can even create anti-creeper or terraform the land around you to add even more to this games amazing functions. Overall this game has a very unique and formidable foe and is the best and one of the most exhilarating strategy games I have ever played.

Graphics/Sounds
I love the look of the creeper, weaponry, even the terrain. The music fits with the game giving an adventurous and formidable feel of the unknown.

Pros/Cons
Pros

+ Unique game playstyle
+ Enormous amount of replayability
+ Addicting
+ Ranges from super easy to maps where you will wonder who was sadistic enough to make it
+ Huge amount of maps to play
+ Good story
+ Map editor

Cons

- May becomes repetitive to some

Final Thoughts
I remember playing the first Creeper World on kongregate and thinking I love this game
date: holy crap it's amazing". Next came Creeper World 3: Abraxis and I played it the moment it was available and again loved it but wished there was more than the 12 missions and then around a year later I got Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal on steam.  I love the game
recommended:
just love it. This is definitely one of my favourite games to ever play. I also found out a while ago a new game which I think is called Particle Fleet is being developed by Knuckle Cracker and I really hope it makes its eventual way onto steam since it looks amazing. This game to me is a piece of true satisfaction and fun. This is a mix of two of my favourite types of games which are RTS and Tower Defense and it has combined those two perfectly in my opinion.

TL;DR
Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is a great mix of RTS and Tower Defense games. It has a unique and constantly attacking foe known as the Creeper and is an astounding strategy game. If you are unsure whether to get this game or not check out Creeper World 3: Abraxis on kongregate to get an idea of the basics of the game and general gameplay."

reviewText:
What happens when you combine a tower defense game with supreme commander?
Creeper World 3 happens, and if you like any of the two before mentioned games then you should have a great time with this one!

You will not fight brain dead enemies who just walk down a single lane. Instead you have fight in all directions against a nano-machine like blob that is ever expanding across the battlefield. Add in attack robots, airstrikes and other nasty suprises and your in for a tough but fun game!

Contentwise Creeper World 3  offers quite alot for such a small title. A campaign with an interesting story (yes a td/strategy game with a story) unlockable bonus levels and the ability to create and share your own maps with the rest of the community.
All this combined will give you HOURS of challenging fun and replayability.

The sound effects and overall visuals are pretty basic but they get the job done. The soundtrack on the other hand is quite nice despite just having a handfull of tracks.

reviewText: I've been a fan of the series since the original.\n\nIn a nutshell the game is hard to put in a nutshell. It's vaguely reminicesent of tower defense titles, but with an absolutely monstrous, game-defining twist. The enemy is not units, but rather Creeper-goop that covers the map and damages or destroys your structures on contact. The game is to fight back, and then destroy the goop spigots-emitters"- or complete other objectives. The structures and enemies are all very simple and direct in their purpose and utility. The game itself however is extremely various in difficulty based on the map itself-size
recommended: and the strength of the emitters. There are additional enemies in addition to the emitters but they are not in all maps.  The challenge of the game is all about defending yourself while you build your energy resources up before you push to destroy the emitters. Later
hoursPlayed:
you can redo the maps to attempt to do so faster.

The game has a great custom map communtiy and a custom map generator after you finish the decently long and challenging campaign. Replayability is top notch.

I've gotten more fun and more hours out of this than a shameful number of AAA titles. All things considered

GeneralAt the time of the writing of this review, I've currently played a mere two hours of this game. I am hooked. Although the videos of the game make it look complicated and mask its true nature, I can assure the reader that it feels like a proper tower defence game. I am a big fan of the StarCraft turret defence" games of old
date: and I'm particularly enamoured with TD games which allow you to maze. This game may not involve mazing
recommended: but you can freely place buildings and "towers" anywhere you deem fit. Do not feel dismayed by the lack of monsters and lack of paths. The "creeper" (which is the enemy) is a creative way of presenting said enemy. It is much too easy to think of it as StarCraft zerg creep to be honest
hoursPlayed: and needless to say it is not nice stuff. I feel that this game has been lovingly crafted
voteText: and I'm looking forward to the replayability that other reviewers have mentioned.\n\nGameplayYour objective is to defeat the creeper on each world. You do this by building up an energy grid and using that energy to build and maintain various weapons (akin to the traditional TD tower). These weapons can move to a new location as you push the creeper further back
helpfulPercent: and they can be upgraded at the forge.\n\nControlsYou use the keyboard and the mouse. All of the buildings
votesHelpful: and many actions are linked to hotkeys
votesTotal: and those hotkeys can be rebound. Unfortunately the build menu does not tell you the hotkey when you hover
votesFunny: so you must go into the key bindings menu to discover what the hotkeys are in the first place. However
commentsCount: once you've learned them they are easy to get along with.\n\nStorylineThere is a plot in the Arc Eternal galaxy. It is fairly basic
column16: and mostly explains the existence of the creeper. I didn't know what precisely was going to happen
column17: but I certainly had a general idea of what direction the plot was going in. But this isn't the sort of game you play for the plot after all.\n\nSoundThe music is fun
column18: it's energetic. However it is very repetitive. If I play this in the evening
column19: I go to bed with the music stuck in my head.\n\nGraphicsThe graphics are pleasant and functional. Things seem a tad fuzzy if you zoom in really close
column20: but I personally like to have an overall view of the map and so I don't zoom in close. Otherwise
column21: despite all the layers upon layers of creeper
column22:
the game runs quite well for me and is not laggy.

Pros+ non-traditional tower defence
+ free placement and movement of "towers"
+ can rebind hotkeys
+ default hotkeys make sense once learned
+ make your own maps and play others' maps (great replayability)
+ wide range of difficulty level (depending on map)
+ first levels of campaign form a tutorial on how to play
Cons- music is repetitive
- hotkeys are not immediately obvious

reviewText: An interesting take on the tower defense genre.  In a lot of ways it plays a lot more like a conventional RTS, with interesting resource management, movable units, and requiring the player to offensively attack enemy structures, rather than sitting back and waiting.   Instead of fighting discrete enemies, you battle back a flow of liquid-like creeper.  Most levels have multiple viable strategies to beat them, giving the player a lot of decisions on how to tackle a level.\n\nThe game features a massive amount of content, with a lengthy, well written campaign, along with nearly infinite player created and procedurally generated levels.

reviewText: I found this gem in a bundle that I had purchased. It's a mix between an endless tower defense and a real time strategy game. a purple ooze gradually expands and you have to defend against it and attack it, slowly expanding and growing your base.\n\nI did feel like eventually I found a strategy that would work against most maps. Defend as large an area as you can, and then slowly but surely break through and take what you need. reviewText:
9/10, would highly recommend.

I remember playing this game many years ago, loving the fresh take on the typical flash-based TD genre. Being the third iteration of the game, it returns to it's roots after the admittedly mediocre sequel.
With classic gameplay from the first, a new campaign, new features and enemies, and a gazillion new user-created and randomly generated levels to play, this game is almost infinitely replayable.

I only have one issue with the game: Difficulty.
You are expected to play agressively and take risks against the already agressive creeper; I find this quite difficult as a player who likes to take things slow and cautiously, but that's just me.

Overall it's an amazing game and a fresh take on an over-used genre.

PS. If you enjoyed the sandbox TD style of this game, you should check out 'Harvest: Massive Encounter', another favourite of mine.
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by its rather plain appearance. This is one of the most addictive and stellar strategy/defense games on Steam.

Struggling to build a small base and inching forward against an overwhelming and powerful enemy only to eventually gain the upper hand and wipe it of the board with massive power is satisfying again and again and again and again.

There is a lengthy campaign, hundreds of bonus maps, an active hub with constantly updated and often stellar community maps and basically infinite, auto-generated maps.

This is a stellar game and an absolute steal for the price.

reviewText: Absolutely smashing. One of those rare pearls that leave the plot, graphics and narrative to the background and focus on pure gameplay. Additionally not only does this game reward borderline autistic heat gradient calculations but it also offers ample oppoturnities to roleplay as a mentally ill commander that has peculiar obsessions when it comes to unit deployment. Shooting blue mass of mathematics with red things of reduction has never been more addictive.\n\nBut infinite replayability isn't enough for the Creeper World community. As such you are able to enjoy a continous flow of new maps tailored by the active community members. Do you enjoy tough-as-nails survival campaigns? Situations where you aim to clear the field expanding from a small but indestructible base with the computer assisting you? Well sure as **** no you don't you casual Dota 2 babby but in a review these kind of questions are supposed to be purely rhetoric.

reviewText:
(日本語レビューは下のほう)

This Strategy game is about fighting liquid-like enemies called Creeper, which aren't explosive but dangerous enough to damage/destroy your buildings on touch.

Game is relatively simple : Build a network of Collectors for more energy. Have some turrets to keep Creepers at bay. Advance to their Emitter and destroy it with Nullifier(its range is short and takes time to activate, be sure to deal with creepers first).
It contains more than thousands of official levels, short maps are finishable within 3 minutes or so, and some epic maps would take 2 or more hours.
There's even a leaderboard competes for time taken to beat the level"
date: and some people seem to be really good at finding clever tactics or optimize their moves.\n\nThe game has a built-in map editor and script editor
recommended: which allows you to make interesting maps once you know how. I'm hoping to see good levels to play.\n\n12/10
hoursPlayed: One of the best RTS I played in all the time. I played all the 3 series of Creeper World
voteText:
and love it best.

--------------------------------
液体状の敵「クリーパー」と戦うRTS。緑色の爆発する皆のアイドルではない。

ゲームプレイは比較的シンプル。「コレクター」を建ててエネルギー供給とネットワークを作り上げ、各種砲台でクリーパーと戦う。どんどん前線を押し進めてクリーパーの発生源である「エミッター」を破壊する(ただし破壊できる「ヌリファイアー」は建設に時間がかかる上に脆いので、発動までちゃんと守ること)。
マップは公式で用意されたものだけでも数千以上あり、３分程度で終わる小型マップから数時間かけて攻略する難易度や規模のマップまでバラエティは豊富。
クリア時間を競うリーダーボードもあり、上位のスコアの異常な速さは戦略の自由さと効率化の重要性を語っている(チートの線も否めないレベルってのもあるが)。

あとマップ/スクリプトエディタも同梱で、作られたマップを公開、他者のマップをプレイして評価できる機能もある。これからのコミュニティの動きに期待できる。

個人的点数は12/10。「最高のRTS」と聞かれたら挙げられそうなレベル。３作ともプレイ済みだが、３を一番薦めたい。"

reviewText:
Full disclaimer: I am a huge fan of the first 2 creeper worlds, the following review maybe … ok it is totally biased.  (Also,  Big thank you to the one of the sweetest guys in the world for buying this for me before I could buy it for myself!)

@ 9 hours in--

I flat out knew I was going to love the third installment of the creeper world saga; but I was unexpectedly blown away.  I was pulled right back into the story and found myself once again needlessly spending 30 + minutes covering planets in collectors and eliminating all traces of  creeper before clamming my wins just because I could. Quickly new mechanics were introduced and my strategies needed to be adjusted, keeping the game play from being stale for returning players.  The game includes a awesome tutorial for new comers … but I would start at the beginning of the story and pick up the 3 pack (for just a few bucks more) at the developers site: http://knucklecracker.com/

The game is a must buy for lovers of strategy and tower defense games.

reviewText:
I'm not a big RTS player, but I found myself playing this for hours, upon hours - straight. This game doesn't look like much, but it delivers an interesting twist with the gameplay that I haven't found in many RTS games. EXTREMELY ADDICTIVE, you have been warned!

I'd say it plays like a slower style RTS like Supreme Commander, mixed with tower defence. However, there is a strong online competetive speed running intention behind this game. Best of both worlds kind of thing I guess. You can make and share your own maps. Play and complete on other people maps. I love how little download wait time there is between trying new maps. Literally, a few seconds.

The down sides, I'm not a huge fan of the artwork. I find it corny and unpleasnt looking. Nonetheless, it works somehow in this setting. There is also a lack of diversity, variation, and depth, with the units and enemies. Each unit has it's strict purpose like in a tower defence game. The outcome can become rather predictable and static. But don't let that stop you from trying this game! It's really fun.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
While my playclock there is probably half again what I have actually played, I have played a lot of this game. I have a few top 10 high scores (look for Seika), I've completed the story, and whole heck of a lot of missions in Tormented Space area (hard mode), so I have quite a bit of familiarity with the game.

Pros:
-A unique take on strategy that generally emphasizes resource and space management more than managing unit tactics, and the enemy is a rather literal tide rather than a more discreet set of units
-Huge array of playable content, with a wide variety of maps.
-Once you clear the main campaign, there are three main modes of pre-constructed maps. Prospector Zone has literally hundreds if not thousands of hours of content, Tormented Space exists for a good challenge, and Alpha Sector has some interesting and often difficult custom maps.

Cons:
-There is little to no AI to speak of. Certain types of enemies are capable of either roaming around randomly, and another will target random sections of your grid, but otherwise, the enemy will follow a strict pattern every map. Except for speed running, there is little point to replaying a map.
-Music will get repetitive.There is a mute button for a reason.
-Once you clear the main campaign, there are three modes. Prospector Zone is where much of the game's content lies, but the (generally) lower difficulty and lack of custom scripting means that most of these maps will get boring and repetitive. Tormented Space is not always the best tested: Some maps will feel almost as easy as the tutorial, while others are quite literally impossible without cheating (there is a thread on the Knuckle Cracker Forum dedicated to which maps are super difficult, which are insanely difficult [often requiring odd tricks in order to even stand a chance], which are possibly impossible, and which are undeniably impossible). If I have any complaint about Alpha Sector, it is that many of these maps were designed by some of the best players to be at their level, so it can be hard to make progress through those missions.

The game can feel repetitive, particularly playing too much in too short a time, but the game has kept me hooked. I would recommend playing this game to anyone who enjoys puzzles and strategy, or who likes playing unique games.

reviewText:
It's World of Goo vs. The Blob!

The Creeper is a simple, slow moving liquid and you have a literal army of sophisticated gadgets to fight it. However, you need to gather resources, build defenses, and figure out how to actually fight back while The Creeper ever slowly creeps closer and closer. At least, that's how things start out. Soon, you begin to find out why multiple human space empires could have fallen to this deceptively simple-looking enemy...

Each level provides a different challenge, and after you play a few levels it becomes obvious why this game has three installments already. It doesn't look like much, but then, neither does The Creeper. The game itself, like The Creeper, is deceptively easy to underestimate, but if you like strategy games, building games, or puzzle games, you should give this a try. There's nothing quite like it.

reviewText:
Good.

No, I'm talking /really/ good.
I've followed this game ever since it came out as a small flash game on the whateverso game sites. It was amasingly simple but had this level of depth that not many other games at the time has, yet after a full release of the game and the founding of Knucklecracker it got even better! I'm going to ignore CW2, even though it introduced a pethora of great ideas, I personally thought it was rash and unpolished. Then they released CW3, and OH MAN this is a good game. not only did it finish up the ideas from 2, it also inserted it into the CW1 style, top-down, tower offence gameplay, and added an open code CRPL engine so that content creators can program ideas and new gamemodes into the system. This is a great game, it's all I can say.

Although I wished it kept all of my stats when it transferred it over to steam :<

most people will see this and switch to the next game and thereby miss one of the greatest games available at the moment. There is so much depth and replayability in this game it's a shame that its presentation prevents it from reaching a larger audience. Having played computer games since the early days of the C64 I saw this game in a bundle somewhere and immediately knew I had to have it. Luckily for me it even was available in a Linux version and for virtually nothing - considering how much fun I had with this game since then I feel like I robbed the developer!

Needless to say that I recommend this game to anyone that has some affinity to tower defense or strategy games in general. Even if you are turned off by the graphics - give it a try! If you don't like it you wasted a (compared to the full price titles) tiny amount of money
date: but if you don't give it a try you might miss out on a gem that will give you many hours of enjoyment ;)\n"

reviewText:
Creeper World 3 is, by far, the most unique game to be found in the Tower Defense genre. Manage supply lines and fueling costs as you take the fight to the enemy; balancing defense with offense. The enemy in this case is an ever-pooling substance which enroaches on the planet. Perfectly simulated, the entity overflows and spills out into the environment in a believable manner. It's up to you to repel and, eventually, destroy it at the source.

Pros:
+ Great difficulty curve. Not too hard, not too easy.
+ Brilliant concept.
+ Managing supply and energy costs is fluid and satisfying.
+ Presentation is simple and effective; height/depth is easy to see at a glance.

Cons:
- Lack of tooltips can lead to confusion.
- Where did the last 3 hours of my life go?
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Creeper World 3 is quite a unique game, it feels like a tower defense game mixed with real-time-strategy elements.

Like in most other RTS games, you have to build a base, though here it is more like a 'power grid', which is essential to power all your defensive and offensive structures. The main difference here though, is the enemy. Instead of tanks, humans or monsters, you have a lava like liquid, that slowly creeps its way to your base and tries to 'fill' the entire map.

It's called 'The Creeper'. I know, it sounds like the name of a cheap 60s horror movie, but it's not.

Anyways, most of the time you'll build turrets, mortars, jet fighters and bombers to defend yourself from The Creeper. But usually that's not enough. You also have the option to 'terraform' the environment. That way you can either dig trenches, or, which is a lot more effective, raise the terrain to wall off your base.

The whole process is quite a lot of fun, especially when you unlock things like the Bertha, which is a giant cannon, or the Thor, which is a giant spaceship with multiple turrets that rains death from above.

The thing I like the most about Creeper World 3 is that you can play whatever way you like. This might be the slow and defensive way, or the fast and offensive way. This is quite important if you care about getting in the top 10 list of each map. These lists are primarily sorted by how much time it took you to complete the map, though to be honest, you'll have a hard time beating the best times, since they're usually around 20 to 30 seconds for each map. This is especially frustrating because I doubt those times are legit most of the time.

All in all though, Creeper World 3 features a huge amount of content, which is good if you like getting your money worth. It's also bad if you want to 100% this game, because judging by the amount of levels, it might take you hundreds of hours to do so.

There's also the fact that you can make your own maps, and play other players maps right inside the game. This gives Creper World 3 almost infinitive content, though some player created levels might be too easy, or even impossible to beat.

Conclusion: Amazing game with an enormous amount of re-playability, easily worth the full price if you're a fan of tower-defense/RTS type of games.

reviewText: The Creeperworld series is by far one of my favourite time wasters. Like others that I have read, I played the first 2, including the extra missions, all on Kongregate and eagerly awaited this third installment. I'm so glad to see it here on steam as the Dev can finally make a decent buck from his amazing efforts!\n\nWhat makes Creeperworld games so unique amongst other tower defence games is the energy currency system. Unlike other games that require you to save your resources, research, etc etc until you can build what you want, you have the ability to build straight away and as many of each structure as you like. The danger lies that the energy required to build, is the same energy required to fire weapons. So if you exhaust too much energy into building, you will surely die! This is balanced by the fact that the more collectors" you spread across the map
recommended: so there is always an incentive to keep building!\n\nAlthough not as graphically amazing as some TD such as Kingdom rush

With one great advantage... NULLIFIERS!! You can explode those nasty emitters. reviewText:
Great game, great value for money, extremely addictive and eats the hours of your day like minutes
Don't let the simple graphics style put you off, this game plays a lot better than it looks. From simple early levels the game introduces new weapons and options into your arsenal and steadily picks up the difficulty. Gameplay is very good and purple goo makes a surprisingly scary enemy, especially in later levels where the flow of creeper encroaches on your base frighteningly fast.
Value for money wise this game really is great value. When I bought it it was marked down slightly to £10.70 and has already surpassed my requirement of giving me an hour of gameplay for every £1 I spent even if I'd paid the full price
If I had to put an arbitrary score on the game I'd happily give it a 9/10 on it's engaging gameplay, ability to make hours pass like minutes and value for money, only missing out on a point because it could maybe have been a little prettier to look at

reviewText:
A few months back, I bought this game after seeing it featured on a Let's Play channel that I follow. I loved it. Now it's featured on Steam, and that was worth me buying the game again.. :V

Essentially, Creeper World 3 is a simple, yet very addicting RTS game. Your task: to liberate planets from the Creeper, which is a living liquid substance that had flooded and destroyed civilizations for millions of years. The story mode campaign is pretty much an extended tutorial that teaches you about all of the gear and units that you will acquire along the way. Once you have gotten so far into the story mode, you can unlock access to other Zones, which is where the game truly opens up.

These Zones have tons of star systems, each with their own collection of planets. Basically, you are free to explore hundreds (if not thousands) of levels of Creeper-fighting goodness. There is also a Map Editor mode in which you can create your own maps to upload to the community. You can also download maps that others have created, and rate them. If all of that still isn't enough, there is a Dial Map" service
date: which is a seed-based random map generator. So many potential battlefields..\n\nSo
recommended: yeah. Great game. Keep on fightin' that flood!"

reviewText:
I've got 90+ hours on this game and that's just since it became available on Steam. This is an amazing RTS game. Think of a tower defense / base building game. You have to be careful with your resourses and either turtle or blitz the enemy spawners. The enemy in this game is more like a liquid that flows around the maps however their are other types of enemies (aerial, and ones that disable your equipment for a brief time.)

The story is amazing and one of the best features is the robust map building engine. The game comes with it's own language for programming how the enemy responds and reacts and you can do some very interesting concepts. Thousands of player-created maps that you can browse through, download, play, rate... just well thought out and well done.

If you enjoy this game, I'd highly recommend buying the first two as well.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've pumped a lot of hours in this game for a simple reason: it's lots of fun!

The game doesn't punish you for playing slow on most maps (I'm a huge turtler), but finishing a map fast (for a higher score) is a real challenge. There's a huge number of maps included and then there's tons of community maps to download as well, the possibilities are near endless.
If you're looking for a game that you can both play leisurely or intensily, this is a good candidate.
The story is fun, but not something you'd write home about. What really makes this game is the simplicity of the enemy: liquid. Yes, you're fighting, what seems like, a dangerous blue liquid.

Enjoy.

reviewText:
I have played all three Creeper games, and loved them all. I liked the first better than the second, so when the third returned to the same style of gameplay, yet improved, buying it was a no-brainer.
I have played many hours on number 3 before it gor released on steam, and more after.

Most levels consist of establishing a beach head / base then beating back the unrelenting flow of creeper. When you reach their spawners, you can destroy them. When the last is gone, you win the map. Other levels have a master spawner that when killed destroys the others. Do you head straight for this one, or soften up the resistance first? The choice is yours.
Your main recource, energy, is often the most deciding factor.

Pro's:
- Nice long story arc.
- Endless ways to complete levels.
- Replayability to beat your previous best time.
- Level editor.
- Big community of custom levels.
- A ton of levels ship with it outside of the story arc.
- Programmable units (for custom levels).

Con's:
- Easy levels can get repetetive (Just mopping up")
- Some of the smaler maps are insanely hard (could also be a Pro rather that a Con... ;-) )

Graphics / sound:
The game has simplistic graphics which is nice to look at
recommended: not so dazzling and cluttered as to confuse you. The soundtrack is good for the first few hours
hoursPlayed:
but wheres a bit thin as the hours rack up. It can be muted in favour of what ever you like.


I give this game 10 / 10
voteText: It is one of the few games I keep returning to for another couple of maps.\n\n(PS! Creeper 1 and 2 are not avaliable on Steam. Visit knucklecracker.com if you are interested)"

reviewText:
I picked this game up one afternoon during the summer sale and started playing.

When I stopped, it was shortly before sunrise.

So it's rather successful by that measure. It's quite satisfying to take back ground from the creeper, and when one word is safe, jump right into the next. One more level. I don't think I've played the other Creeper World games, but it feels like after years of making them they've got a pretty good handle on what makes a Creeper World game work in that regard.

I've just finished the main Arc Eternal campaign, after 27 hours. (I play defensively and pause a lot. Your mileage may vary.) The campaign is pretty good at making each level just a little different, providing some new element of challenge and giving you a new ability to use. Some levels are more different than others.

The game's weakest moments, I think, are the maps that become simply an ocean of creeper. Any distinctive features of the terrain are all but lost under the sea, as you slowly entrench and advance. Maybe more aggressive tactics could prevent ending up in that situation, but since I wasn't actually losing those battles, I didn't give up and try different techniques. Then came along a different map that makes things interesting again.

This isn't the sort of game you play for the story. Yet there is a story, told in bits of dialog at the beginning and ending of levels, which shows some significant thought has gone into the lore of the Creeper. I might have appreciated it more if I was familiar with the other games, but it provides some interesting atmosphere.

I can't comment on the other content outside the main campaign, but there seems to be a lot of it, with a strong focus on giving the community powerful tools to make more.

I played this on Linux (Ubuntu 14.04). Everything ran great there; the only hitch I found is that after switching out of the window with Alt-Tab, I had to hit Alt again after returning to the game to get the keyboard input recognized correctly.

To sum up: Surely not everyone likes this style of game. But if you're interested in this sort of thing (which you likely are, if you're looking into the reviews), I recommend it without reservation. It's an excellent implementation of the idea.

And also very good if you want to forget to eat or sleep.

reviewText:
Creeper World is technically a tower defence game, but unlike any other you've played before.

In a normal tower defence game (and even abnormal awesome ones like Defender's Quest) you'll have enemies coming towards a point or object you're defending and you're tasked with fending them off by placing towers either along a pre-defined path or by creating that path using walls or the towers themselves (this is known as 'mazing').
In Creeper World there is only one enemy, the Creeper. The Creeper is a fluid of alien origin and malicious intent, it absorbs and destroys anything constructed it touches. This changes the entire dynamic and feel of the game.

The goal (in most levels) is to activate totems that are strewn about the (bird's eye perspective 2D) map without having your base be destroyed by creeper. Creeper flows in continuously from spawn points and you build out a network of structures from your command ship to fend off the creeper (or even destroy its spawn points). The buildings are either combat focused (the traditional tower defence type towers) or utilitarian.
Because the resource system is quite different from a regular tower defence game as well (and is surprisingly similar to Supreme Commander / Total Annihilation instead), you have 'Energy' which is used to build structures, arm your towers and charge up totems. Energy is stored in your command ship and then flows along the nodes formed by the buildings you created, like a spider web that slowly grows outward (and not unlike the creeper that slowly washes over the map).

A simple level progression would be to land your command ship at a strategically good location (high ground, remember that your enemy is basically a liquid so it'll flow into the low spaces first), start building collectors (buildings that gather energy from their direct surroundings) and laser towers to protect the collectors which you slowly move up with the front as the collector field grows in size (all offensive towers can be moved across the map whenever you want).

Of course things get far more complicated later on, with the addition of new towers including mortars, bombers and snipers. New enemies like a creeper-formed network that will always transmit the creeper even if it's uphill, building-disabling enemies living on this network and even aerial creeper that will occasionally spawn from specific enemy buildings and head for your base.

All these things (and a lot more) are slowly introduced over the course of an excellent 30 or so campaign that even has a pretty engaging storyline (the game is set thousands of years after Creeper World 1 and 2, so you don't need to know all that much from them to get the gist of things. Unfortunately they were never released on Steam. For a sample of the gameplay from Creeper World 1 and 2 (and even 3, in case you want to try it out) there are in-browser options available here[www.kongregate.com]).

There is one mission right at the end of one of the two branches of the game's plot that is very different from the others though, and not in a good way. Unlike pretty much the rest of the game it has a time limit, and a harsh one at that. In the rest of the game (especially within the campaign) it's pretty hard to lose as long as you take things slow and don't over-extend yourself. This one mission completely messes that up and asks you to rush in and beat the clock. It's not a bad concept I guess, but terribly executed and I ended up downloading an in-mission savegame in order to bypass it because I just couldn't beat it.

Other than that single (but major) gripe there is nothing but praise for this game. The campaign mode (which will last you a good long while) is only the tip of ice berg, as there are thousands upon thousands of additional levels that you will need a lifetime to complete. These range from fun levels the beta testers came up with, to nasty challenge levels the creator put in, to a whole universe of bonus levels, to procedurally generated levels. There is also an in-game level editor, complete with a way to directly share them with others and play their levels and tools to change anything in the game.

Go give the game's free version a shot, and if the gameplay at all grabs you this is an excellent value purchase. Just remember that there's one super annoying mission in the campaign mode.

reviewText:
Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is a under-the-radar tower-defense game that is both fun and challenging. It's basic yet complex appearance may overwhelm those new to the genre, but Knuckle Cracker did a good job on slowly pacing the user into the concepts around Creeper World 3.

The graphics of Creeper World 3 aren't anything extraordinary but they are pretty solid. The terrain is in a variety of colors and the illusion of layers is clearly there. The various tools and weapons stand out from the terrain and are simple to realize through the variation in shape and color. While everything looks basic throughout the game, the graphics are crisp and clear - and that's good enough for a tower defense game.

The core gameplay of Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is one that is new to me. While I have played other games in the same sort of genre, Creeper World 3 is unique in the sense that it's attempting to fuse both Tower Defense and Strategy-Simulation. While the majority of tower defense's have you place your weapons on a certain path as enemies start to come at you on a predictable path - Creeper World 3 is adds a refreshing twist. Your enemy is the creeper. The creeper spreads outward in all directions, covering the terrain and destroying everything in it's path. It is your job to use the weapons at your disposal to take out the source of the creeper - being the emmiters. While it may not sound that hard, which it really isn't at first; the difficulty begins to ramp up. It will be very challenging for newcomers - including me at times, but I never really felt that the game was cheating. I also realized what mistakes I made if I were to fail. Throughout the game, you will play a variety of maps with the inclusion of the story. The story arc is the weakest point about this game, it's very forgettable and did nothing to increase the immersion or gameplay. It's a good effort nonetheless. The mouse controls are also great - with the ability to pause the game, plan you moves and move your units around where you please. Overall, the core mechanics of Creeper World 3 is great and will be something for all games in the similar genre to beat.

The audio is good for a game like this. In all honestly, what can you expect. The music is fine with the occasion of it being repetitive. I found myself turning off the music at various times. The sound effects are pretty simple. Nothing special here.

Creeper World 3's greatest strength is it's value. Like Skyrim, Portal 2 and Torchlight 2 before them, the sheer amount of user content is mind-blowing. At a cheap price of $15, it's pretty hard to not pick this one up if you are a fan of the genre. There are an abundance of maps, both pre-made and user-made all varying in difficulty. It's also good to note that some maps have been known as unbeatable. A random map generator is also here as well as an in-game editor to create your own maps for others to try. Creeper World 3 also has over 130 achievements for those who are into them.

In conclusion, Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal was one of the more surprising buys for me. I didn't think I would enjoy the game this much. It is something I will continue to play for years to come.

GRAPHICS: 8.0/10
GAMEPLAY: 9.5/10
STORY: 5.0/10
AUDIO: 7.0/10
CONTROLS: 9.0/10
VALUE: 10/10

OVERALL: 8.1/10

+Refereshing take on genre
+Challenging yet Fun
+Solid Controls
+Addictive
+Great Variety in Maps and Units
+Overwhelming amount of content
+130+ Achievements
+Inexpensive

+/- Some Unbeatable Maps

-Weak Story
-Repetitive Music
-Can sometimes be a grind

reviewText: A surprisingly satisfying experience, Creeper World 3 combines a compelling mystery-story about an enigmatic and impossibly powerful enemy with the satisfaction of a tower defense game that allows you to precisely nail that moment of satisfaction that comes when you just barely gain the upper hand, and turn the tables on an opponent that has had you against the ropes for most of the battle.......or at least that's what I experienced with my turtle-style gameplay; blocking off key points and slowly amassing an economic juggernaut that allows me to employ brute-force tactics and give the enemy a taste of his own medicine, so to speak. The story I found to be equally enjoyable, so much so that I found myself making sure to play through every planet of a given sector in a single session just so I could move on to the next and hear more of the narrative. It also included a worthwhile (if a bit predictable) twist at the end.\n\n9 / 10
One of the best casual games ever (along with the first two Creeper Worlds). After you beat the campaign, user-made maps (downloaded in-game) will keep you busy forever.

The story mission in this game can take quite some hours to beat depending on your skills, and once you are near completion of the story missions you realize how much more content the game has to offer, it has lots of extra maps to unlock and if you get bored with that you can download community based maps or make your own.

The maps consist of 10 different heights on which creeper flows (a living all consuming liquid), on each map there are emitters that will slowly fill up the map with this creeper.
You will need to build shields, cannons and mortars to defend your base while building energy gathering structures to keep things running, you will get slowly stronger and the defense will gradually become offence until you can destroy the creeper emitters.

You can manipulate the height of the map with a certain structure to flatten the ground, build a giant wall against the creeper or dig a hole for it.

The faster you take over and beat the map, the higher your score will be, it is all about speed and managing your energy levels.

It is not really a TD game it is more like a balance war, whether you or the creeper grows fastest.

Creeper world 3 is an exciting, TD/RTS game.  Although the concept is simple (destroy a blue, water like substance, 'Creeper') the story is well designed with a big twist towards the end of the campaign. The aim of the game is to build towers to defeat the creeper and destroy the creeper emitters. You unlock these towers by finding them on different planets, as you fly around space.

Hundreds more levels were created for you to play after the campaign, some taking hours to complete. You can even create your own missions, or play other peoples creations, meaning you will never run out of content.

Creeper world 3 can be a bit slow at times, so you may not enjoy the game as much as some people. But I certainly think it is worth the £10.99.

(Don't be discouraged by my small amount of time played, most of my time played is on another profile)

I've been a huge Creeper World fan since I played the flash demo of the original release.  It's was the first time I ever paid an indie dev directly for a game.   After losing my serial key, and resorting to pirating, and griefing the dev on his personal forum about how stupid serial keys are, I swore I wouldn't him pay again until I could buy it from a proper distribution service.  Of course I wasn't going to not play CWII, so I pirated just, just like I warned him.  Basically, I've given this dev a lot crap.  At no point, however, have I ever changed my belief that Creeper World is, definitively, the most creative, dynamic, and all around best tower defense game on the market.

Unlike most wave based tower defense games, the eponymous creeper, somewhat akin to the nothing in Neverending Story, literally represents a tide of battle.  You find yourself struggling to mount a last ditch effort of defense in every map, desparate to get your defenses into place before it washes over you.  As you struggle to build up your (de/off)ense, the waves is getting ever higher, denser, and harder to push back.  Then there's that moment;  your towers start pushing back, you inch them forward and add some more.  The creeper starts to wane.  You close in for the kill.  You have conquered insanity.  It was a close call.

CWII was a unique and addictive game in it's own right, bringing plenty of brilliance to the table, and a completely different experience.  Played from a side view, with a variety of new units and resources, it's very much the Zelda II of the series.  I strongly encourage you to play them both, and I hope he brings them to Steam; I will buy them in an instant.

Creeper World III absolutely lives up to the legacy of brilliance.  Not only does it merge all of the extended unit and resources from the second game into the playstyle of the first,  It refines and expands on the concepts to offer a diversity of experience I simply wasn't prepared for.   I kind of expected more of the same, and what I got instead was my mind blown.

Every map is a righteous experience.  The amount of content is mindblowing.  It's the best tower defense game on the market.    Pay this dev, he deserves it.
Brillient! I've played creeper world since it was a free game online. On it's on steam with a great storyline and an impressive amount of levels

One of the best and most unique indie games I've played.  While on its surface it may only look like a simple tower defense game, it brings an incredibly unique spin to the genre by completely removing the upfront cost for buildings in favor of an energy management system, and by having a fluid enemy.  Endlessly replayable, with hundreds of included maps, and thousands more community-made maps available for download.  And if that's still not enough, it comes with a map editor and a procedural map generator, which allows for essentially limitless possibilities.  Don't worry if you've never played Creeper World 1 or 2, the early missions have a tutorial, which walks you through the possible uses for each building.
The best in the series so far, and that's from somebody who's played them all!

reviewText:
This game is so good!  It is by far the best of the Creeper World trilogy, all of which were highly enjoyable.  I completely devoured this game - I had a huge craving for a particular mood of space game, and this more than fit the bill.  The story is very compelling and almost haunting. Creeper World 3 is a pausable RTS-type game with aspects of tower defense at its core, combined with a physics/fluid dynamics twist. The game is very well done, challenging and packed with a number of game modes, along with a powerful integrated editor. It's not ridiculously complicated with dozens of units or a mad clickfest where you need millisecond reaction times to survive -- those games are not really my style, but Creeper World 3 is very satisfying. It can get hectic, but there's always time to pause and breathe.

Terrain (including terraforming), energy networks and advancing your weaponry all play huge roles, and you will definitely be pondering strategies on every map. This is not a puzzler, there's not a single right way" to win each map; given enough time
date: often times even poor strategies can grind out wins. That translates to a lot of flexibility and support for different playstyles and setups.\n\nAs the title suggests

reviewText: If real time strategy games with multiple aspects of play in a future based game with a nearly infinite number of levels to beat is your thing, then this is your game.\n8.5/10 Wasting my life on this game

I remember playing the early flash version of this series YEARS ago. I loved it a lot, like it's 'fighting against an almost literal wall/flood/swarm of enemies' type gameplay. This game is far more polished an has A LOT of content to more than justify the $15 price tag.

A seemingly simple, easy to pick up RTS with mechanics that afford incredible depth. Reminiscent of Total Annihilation (intentionally so, given the inclusion of the signature bertha cannon) and the under appreciated gem perimeter.


There is a great amount of value here for a game of this type. Each level in the campaign introduces a new unit or a new mechanic or just has some kind of unique property to make it interesting which is really the key to any decent RTS campaign. After you 'finish' the main story there is a bounty of user designed maps, wacky beta tester maps and 2 'sectors' of conventional maps with a specific goal in mind, not to mention the ability to design your own maps. Not only is the replay potential limitless it's also really good content in its own right, some of the use made maps are really fun and if you beat it in the fastest time you get to 'claim' it as your own.

If you're into oldschool RTS like red alert 2, starcraft or the aforementioned TA this the ultimate indie game, you wont get a better experience for your money.  I honestly can't believe this was developped by one guy given the amount of content squeezed in and the elegance of the design.
Great TD with an inovatrive enemy and a amazing soundtrack. The story is nothing special but it is enough to keep me reading throu the text boxes

Nice tower defence game.  The main enemy is a fluid that you have to keep at bay and then force into retreat.  Very playable, although not perfect.  Worth looking at if you enjoy tower defence, but maybe not the first tower defence title to buy as a first TD game.\n\nGood enough to recommend.

Currently working my way through the campaign and can say it is horribly addictive once you begin building up your arsenal. The game eases you into what soon becomes a challenging mix of resource gathering and holding back the endless creeper threat.\n\nWell worth a buy and you will sink hours into it!

I've always had a thing for RTS and Tower Defense games, and so when I first found Creeper World on Kongregate, I was overjoyed. There were many different versions available freely there. Recently, I decided to purchase the third installment to see how it was.\n\nThere is much to love about this game. The game follows more or less the same rules throughout, but the final two story missions are definite game changers. I've seen many complain about losing on the second to last mission due to time constraints - I myself lost the first time around, but with a little advice I figured out how to beat it. The consistency of the gameplay can make things a little drab if you play too much, but if you enjoy one level, you're likely to enjoy a whole lot more - and there are a whole lot more. There's an practically endless array of levels once you beat most of the story. You can binge play or play a game every once in a while - either way, it will take you a long time to run out of official maps, and you'll never run out of custom ones. The game isn't all too challenging if you remember to pause frequently and keep tabs on the Creeper and your resources, but there are more difficult levels available if that's what you're looking for. The graphics are solid - nothing incredible, but well-done nonetheless.
Genuinely not terrible!

The story mission in this game can take quite some hours to beat depending on your skills, and once you are near completion of the story missions you realize how much more content the game has to offer, it has lots of extra maps to unlock and if you get bored with that you can download community based maps or make your own.

The maps consist of 10 different heights on which creeper flows (a living all consuming liquid), on each map there are emitters that will slowly fill up the map with this creeper.
You will need to build shields, cannons and mortars to defend your base while building energy gathering structures to keep things running, you will get slowly stronger and the defense will gradually become offence until you can destroy the creeper emitters.

You can manipulate the height of the map with a certain structure to flatten the ground, build a giant wall against the creeper or dig a hole for it.

The faster you take over and beat the map, the higher your score will be, it is all about speed and managing your energy levels.

It is not really a TD game it is more like a balance war, whether you or the creeper grows fastest.
One of the best casual games ever (along with the first two Creeper Worlds). After you beat the campaign, user-made maps (downloaded in-game) will keep you busy forever.
Looks simple and kinda goofy at first glance. Amazing. Deep. At least try the demo.
Tower Defense with water as the enemy. Very fun. Very addictive. 10/10.\n\nCheck out the original Creeper World, too.
Oh my god. This game is incredible. Stupidly addictive, networky, turrent defendy goodness. Lovely visuals and just excellent audio.

Simple game, really. The only difference in levels are the levels themselves; using the same tatics will get you through most of the game. Yes it is repetitive and yes it isn't graphically next gen, but it is incredibly addictive. If you wish to pass the time and have some money to throw around (or get it at $5 during a sale) then I recommend this game.

A simple yet painfully addictive game! Many different ways to play against a never ending flow of enemy goop, fliers, and other weird... erhmm... things?! Levels can be finished in minutes or multiple hours depending on your play style. My strategy of high walls and moats makes things last longer than it should but it's still enjoyable! Good purchase!! :)
Brillient! I've played creeper world since it was a free game online. On it's on steam with a great storyline and an impressive amount of levels

Do you love Strategy games?
Do you love Tower defense games?

If you said yes then you're gonna love this game.
Should you find yourself bored during the day, Load this game up and have some fun!
with plenty of levels and a rather interesting storyline you won't wanna stop till you completed it!

One of the best and most unique indie games I've played.  While on its surface it may only look like a simple tower defense game, it brings an incredibly unique spin to the genre by completely removing the upfront cost for buildings in favor of an energy management system, and by having a fluid enemy.  Endlessly replayable, with hundreds of included maps, and thousands more community-made maps available for download.  And if that's still not enough, it comes with a map editor and a procedural map generator, which allows for essentially limitless possibilities.  Don't worry if you've never played Creeper World 1 or 2, the early missions have a tutorial, which walks you through the possible uses for each building.
The best in the series so far, and that's from somebody who's played them all!

I remember playing the first Creeper World when it was just a flash game, good times. But huge huge improvments. This game is all I can ask for from the dev of this game. The art is well done, controls, sounds, alot of stuff. Not to forget to menton that there is 100s of hours of content for this game like story, level editor, free mode, all sorts of game modes! I did not think twice buying this.

My rating overall is 9.5, why -5? Multiplayer would be cool, but I kinda understand how hard it would be, but still perfect singleplayer gameplay is enough. If you like RTS and a hard stragity based game, this might be just for you! (Later in the game it gets insane almost) Phew that map Farbor you will never forget about it, I almost gave up and it was only like level 10 out of ..50.. or something! And that's not even going to be the ending you can play unlimited of custom maps that people made and such! The community is awesome to.

If you get this game get ready to be addicted for awhile, I suddenly got out of orbit of the addiction somehow.

NOTE!: If you are thinking of getting this game but you don't know then go to Knuckle Cracker looking for Creeper World Evermore (it's free) if you don't like that very much you might wanna keep your money in your wallet. (But there is a shiz ton more features in this one, A TONLDSKJH!"

This is the most satisfying single player experience I've had in a long time. Base building has never been this fun. The main story is actually pretty interesting, and after that, there are a ludicrous number of additional maps to play. Visuals are clear, and the music is top notch. Highly recommended!
VERY addictive game, think tower defence but instead of defending against just mobs your defending against water. Have been playing this since the orginal and am still hooked.

First off, play the preview/demo if you haven't already.  It gives you a very accurate feel for how the full game plays (minus some of the story bits).  If you enjoy that then you will love this game.

I gladly spend hours and hours on this game; sometimes spending over an hour on one map.  Aside from basic landscape changes there really is a lot of variety in how the creeper will advance across the map, which truly requires a new strategy for each map.  I also find the difficulty level good as well.  There's also a random level generator, which may not provide the same challenge as the planned maps, but it still gives unlimited replayability.

Other than maybe the tedious dialog of the story missions I really have nothing bad to say about this game.

WOW best Creeper World ever.  Literally I have never seen a franchise make a 3rd installment that is SO much better than an already great game.\n\nI do not have room to list all the reasons this game rocks...  But it is truly unique among games and oh so addictive!

This is a great game. The first two game are amazing also. I have had the first two for a long while and play constantly. These games are completely replayable. I return to these games when ever I have time, and you really only need about 30mins a map so you can play a really quick game before work. I was waiting for the steam release for a long time and I am glad it has finally come. I would recommend this game to everyone who likes some stategy and fast paced game play.

This game is extremely addicting and fun. Besides the story maps, there are hordes of user created maps, randomly generated maps, challenge maps, and so on. Basically it's a brilliant take on the tower defense genre with a huge amount content.

Excellent game! There's a lot of unique stuff in the game, and experiments with the RTS genre to great effect. The levels are a little time-consuming, but the game-feel is great, and it does a great job of making water" into a viable enemy."

I had the chance to play the first Creeper World back in those good ol flash days. I was profundly impressed by the concept, fluid defense! I got quite hooked for a while, and then there came the following games and expantions, i often wonder where did this guy get all those great ideas for map creation.\n\nThen, a few days back, i saw this on steam, i didnt even saw the presentation, went straight into take my money" mode. Now im scared

reviewText: A good solid tower offense/defense with fluid/thermodynamic physics based enemy and node/packet/network based base building. Collect resources to power and expand your network while defending against, pushing back, and eventually destroying the Creeper.\n\nGets repetitive after a while but creative mods and difficult maps requiring alternate play styles help break the repetition. If you're unsure demo the free flash version(s) first.
Very fun, very time consuming. Buy it, there's more than 15 hours of gameplay here.

I wish I could tell you not to play this game.  If I could do this, I'd be saving you from sheer power of this game's addiction.  Alas, I am weak.  I can't not recommend this game.  For this I am ashamed.\n\nMay you forgive me, and have mercy on my soul.
