reviewText: A genuinely different take on the tower defense genre that has a surprising amount of content and is priced very well. Worth looking at, for sure.

Hello, guys!

I really can't even how good this game is. I've played CW2 before, so I didn't hesitate to buy this game as soon as I've noticed it.

What is CW all about? It's an interesting strategy, where you don't fight against enemy units similar to yours, but massive amounts of creeping blue goo. So it feels a little bit like tower defence, but really innovative one.

The in-game economy system is quite simmilar to one from Supreme Commander (which I loved too!) and it's based more on flow of the resources than stockpiling them. This approach forces costant action, which is nice.

So, does concept still feels to You boring? Fear not, as so far every single map is quite diverse and suprises me with something new (I've completed about 30% of game, and CW2 which was quite brilliant too!). Your enemy sometimes spawns various units too, and the goo doesn't always act like it's expected to.

The game has its own plot, which is not that plain. There are no cosmic civilisations fighting against each other. There's no war, humanity lost against creeper long ago. You've been asleep for 5 billion years. All you can do is crawling through ruins of ceased race of humans, and try to make sense of what happened. Why do I even mention history in such simple game? Honestly, because at this point I am simply curious how will this story end.

The only 2 downsides I've noticed are:
-crappy, plain graphics. I don't think it matters though, as this simpleness comes in one package with perfect gameplay and practical interface.
-lack of multiplayer. Seriously, guys, I don't care, add it somehow!

What do I say at the end? Mabye I'll describe my general feel about it. This game feels like the best flash game ever, but with large campagin and saving and stuff. Buy it. Do it. I don't think anyone would regret doing it, except if it makes him fail his exams or sth.
So different and so much fun!

Oh my. This is addictive. My biggest complaint is that the beginning level(s)  could do a better job of teaching the player. For example, I'm about 5 levels in and I just realized I can move turrents around after placement. And another level I kept failing at because I didn't realize that I could build on top of higher ground - it looked like the creeper had to go through the canyons, so I thought I did as well. But once I got past those issues, I cannot stop playing.
Tower Defense with water as the enemy. Very fun. Very addictive. 10/10.\n\nCheck out the original Creeper World, too.

Most fun I've had with an RTS in ages. You don't have to be any good at strategy games to win at this, but it will take a long time to win if you're terrible like me. Less tedious micromanagement, more economy and map control. Most games play like tug-of-war in an attrition style tower defence format. Every win feels satisfying as the AI can't cheat and the levels are well designed.\n\nVery addictive and a bargain at full price. Similar to the first Creeper World but better in every way.

It may not look like much from the screenshots, but this is a great game.  Plenty of challenge, lots of thinking.  Plenty of pressure not to screw it up.  Grab the demo, then buy it if you like what you see.  It's a worthy game.  Just quit playing it well before you need to sleep unless you want to lie in bed thinking of ways to beat a particularly nasty map rather than sleeping.
Excellent game. Do not buy it if you intend to be a productive adult ever again. I've already lost half my weekend to the thing and barely noticed... run, before it's too late!

Nice little single player game.  Classic RTS look and feel but with an original game play twist.
The creeper oozes towards you.  With guns and terraforming devices you fight back: block its progress and push it back until you can take out its source.

Graphics are somewhat basic and some GUI controls are bit clunky.  But the gameplay compensates for this.
Something different from today's genre clones and repetitive MMO free to play .

If you loved classic RTS games like Dune, Starcraft or early Red Alert then try this.

Just heard of this series thanks to it being on Steam.  Very glad I picked it up - I'm bored to tears with most tower defense type games out there but this is separate from the rest.  Not only due to its new concepts and 'the creeper', but the whole thing is brilliantly executed.  The story is thought provoking and ultimately plausible which is terrifying to me.\n\nAdd to that unlimited user created content, online play, and the ability to customize your own battle maps, and I think I lean towards 5/5 for this
one of the best games in the tower defence/ base building genre, loved the last few creeper world games as well

This game is insanely addictive. I will be honest with you I just got this game today and I've already played for five hours nonstop. First game I've marathoned the day I aquired it since DF: Masterwork. There is so much content already in the game plus you can create your own maps and play on maps created by others! The brain twisting resource management in this game is incredible and the music is pretty good too. Maps can take an hour to complete sometimes but you can save mid-game so it's amazingly flexible. Fending off blue goo is fun, but what if you want red goo? You can even customize the colour of the creep! It's really cool and super fun to play. Not for casual gamers or hardcore shooter fans but if you like strategy games this will take you to a new level of tower defense.

One of the most unique Tower Defense/RTS games I've ever played, with a unique enemy to fight against, plenty of units to build and use backed by a very well implimented resource system, and an absolutely INSANE amount of content. Definatly worth a look.
This game is a snap up to system 2 misson 2.
Great fun. Not all the easy. Addictive as cocaine infused pringles. 11/10

I've been very interested in the Creeper World trilogy for as long as I can possibly remember. I first found a flash game affixed on the engine used in Creeper World 1, Creeper World Training Simulation[www.kongregate.com] on Kongregate, and ever since then I had been searching vigeriously for more Creeper World flash games. Next up was another game created by the engine used for Creeper World 1, Creeper World: Evermore[www.kongregate.com]. Following up on that, I also discovered Creeper World: User Space[www.kongregate.com]. Shortly after, I finally found a flash game affixed to the engine Creeper World 2 was made from, Creeper World 2: Academy[www.kongregate.com]. I had a lot of fun messing around with the anti-creeper there. Eventually, I learned that there was a Creeper World 3 hidden somewhere on the internet, and I looked everywhere for it. Soon, after visiting Knuckle Cracker's website[knucklecracker.com], I learned that Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal had been Greenlit on STEAM. I rushed to get a STEAM Card from Gamestop, and IMMEDIATELY bought Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal without even a second thought. When I started playing, I couldn't take my eyes off of the screen. Not for one second, not for my mom, not for my dad, not for my brother, not even to marvel at my chihuahua when he was rolling over in my room behind me, trying to get my attention. I could not stop for anyone. The story is amazingly well put together, and innovation and the quick thinking strategy it forces you to endorse while playing is absolutely indescribably amazing. I couldn't stop playing No matter how angry I got, or how far I progressed only to have the creeper destroy everything I have built and worked so hard for, I COULD NOT STOP PLAYING!! .... I'm sorry, if I keep this up, I'll be ranting on about how awesome this game is for days.

I often hear this game referred to as a TD game.  There is some truth to that, but I think that falls incredibly short of the magnificance of CW3 which I consider to be more of a RTS.  I originally started playing this series on one of the web portals that had a demo version.  It was such a fun game that once I realized it was a demo of a complete game I jumped into the whole series.  I haven't regretted that at all.  This newest version, in particular, has blown me away with the sheer amount of variation that can come from it.  The main campaign is great...the user built levels are phenomenal.  I'm  constantly in awe with what the community comes up with to create new challenges and the game is so flexible that the skies the limit.  I cannot recommend this game enough!
fun and addictive game. Best and a quite unique tower defense game along with offensive strategy. Just simply a fun game.
Addictive as anything I've ever played.  An amazing mix of tower defence and real time strategy.\nVaried maps, multiple strategies and endless new scenarios!  BUY THIS!

It's like a Tower Defense game and a real-time strategy had a baby.

Do you like the combat puzzle of TGDs? Do you appreciate the magnificent sprawl of your towers? Does the average TGD leave you feeling like all you do is sit back and wait for the enemies to make their move? Then have I got a game for you!

Creeper World 3 is the TGD that forces you to be aggressive. This game changes the Tower Defense rules so much that it is debatable if the term Tower Defense" should even apply.

This is definitely one of the most addictive games I've played in a while. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
I've been a huge Creeper World fan since I played the flash demo of the original release.  It's was the first time I ever paid an indie dev directly for a game.   After losing my serial key, and resorting to pirating, and griefing the dev on his personal forum about how stupid serial keys are, I swore I wouldn't him pay again until I could buy it from a proper distribution service.  Of course I wasn't going to not play CWII, so I pirated just, just like I warned him.  Basically, I've given this dev a lot crap.  At no point, however, have I ever changed my belief that Creeper World is, definitively, the most creative, dynamic, and all around best tower defense game on the market.

Unlike most wave based tower defense games, the eponymous creeper, somewhat akin to the nothing in Neverending Story, literally represents a tide of battle.  You find yourself struggling to mount a last ditch effort of defense in every map, desparate to get your defenses into place before it washes over you.  As you struggle to build up your (de/off)ense, the waves is getting ever higher, denser, and harder to push back.  Then there's that moment;  your towers start pushing back, you inch them forward and add some more.  The creeper starts to wane.  You close in for the kill.  You have conquered insanity.  It was a close call.

CWII was a unique and addictive game in it's own right, bringing plenty of brilliance to the table, and a completely different experience.  Played from a side view, with a variety of new units and resources, it's very much the Zelda II of the series.  I strongly encourage you to play them both, and I hope he brings them to Steam; I will buy them in an instant.

Creeper World III absolutely lives up to the legacy of brilliance.  Not only does it merge all of the extended unit and resources from the second game into the playstyle of the first,  It refines and expands on the concepts to offer a diversity of experience I simply wasn't prepared for.   I kind of expected more of the same, and what I got instead was my mind blown.

Every map is a righteous experience.  The amount of content is mindblowing.  It's the best tower defense game on the market.    Pay this dev, he deserves it.
Very different kind of game.. love the cellular automata feel
This game is AMAZING! An easy 10/10 for me, and I dont even enjoy most tower defense games!

Best RTS tower defence game ever the play is much more complex than any other game of it's kind the campaign isn't to hard but the online maps and challenging sectors provide ulimited play and challenges you should get this game.
Quick-fix
Awesome game, hours of entertainment.

Try the online versions of this game. This is a nice strategy game mostly build on suply lines to me. This is a good price for this game, it has a ok story that you have to read though and can be very difficult. This also suports creating your own maps and downloding tons of other peoples map with simple mulitplayer to see who can finish it the fastest. Do try the free games online and see if you want to support them by buying this game. This does not add that much but it does give you a full big game instead of going online website. However the inteface scale is kinda small and not a lot of mouse overs for the units and some controls could be better. This game makes up for it by having a great window mode and can easly play while doing other things. Overall this game to me is worth the price and is one of my favorite online website games and now I can run it easier and have so much more content.

If you're a fan of tower defence games then I highly recommend you try this, especially if you're looking for something different.

Gameplay: 8/10
Visuals: 5/10
Story: TL;DR/10

The gameplay is an excellent take on the tower defence genre. Your enemy flows like water over the mountains and vallies of the terrain as you fight them back and shape the terrain to keep them out and direct the flow as you pierce forward to destroy their source. Gameplay is kept interesting through unique gameplay elements on specific maps (Such as a map with an orbiting planet past the borders that attracts the tide of enemies towards it as it spins) and a decent array of towers which offer multiple ways to complete any challenge.

The visuals are what let this game down and make it feel like someone's first tower defence game made in flash, at first glance. Pixel art while low resolution can be hard to master, having the visuals of a game like FTL would make this game look incredible.

Gameplay tips:
Terps can be toggled between shaping layers or the closest block
Sprayers can be set to always on"

Deceptively Simple. Truth be told, I thought this game was going to be some simple gimmick game, but the gameplay looked decent enough to try. Although the graphics aren't anything worthy of praise, it's an incredibly simple but effective demonstration of raw real time strategy gaming. The Campaign itself isn't too challenging, but beyond that there are tens and potentially even hundreds of missions which are playable beyond the Campaign, many of which are incredibly challenging in their own right. The economy system is incredibly similar to the likes of Supreme Commander. If you don't mind minimalistic graphics and love a good real time strategy that's really easy to pickup, but difficult to master, then Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal is the game for you.

Creeper World is a tower defense with very unique gameplay and design. Unlike most tower defense games your enemy isn't a horde of monsters, but is instead a steadily expanding mass known as 'creeper'. Defeating the creeper isn't as simple as having strong towers - you have to know how to hold back the creeper while expanding your own area of influence, taking into account the the creeper will ooze in from multiple angles and will build up in areas of low elevation to eventually climb up onto higher ground.

Your own building mechanics are quite interesting as well. Instead of having independent towers, you instead build a web-like network of resource gatherers, utility structures, and attacking towers. Managing this web can get quite tricky at times, because all resources must flow through a command center and take time to traverse the network. Done incorrectly you could end up building a tower but not being able to arm it in time to defend against the creeper.

Also, while the creeper acts as a steadily growing mass, the player often ends up mirroring the creeper in many ways. Collectors - the primary resource generator - are most effective when spread out, forcing the player to expand their area of influence if they want more resources to spend. There are also many resource deposits around the map which must be contested, forcing the player to expand their area of influence even more. Aiding this playstyle is the fact that attacking towers can be respositioned, allowing you to leapfrog towers to slowly but steadily push the creeper back.

Overall the game is an excellent example of a unique twist on a genre and very polished gameplay. It's an extremely satisfying game to play and I highly recommend it to anyone who finds the concept interesting. Don't worry about not playing the previous games - they give more of the story, but this game is fully functional as a standalone experience.

Gameplay: 8/10
Visuals: 5/10
Story: TL;DR/10

The gameplay is an excellent take on the tower defence genre. Your enemy flows like water over the mountains and vallies of the terrain as you fight them back and shape the terrain to keep them out and direct the flow as you pierce forward to destroy their source. Gameplay is kept interesting through unique gameplay elements on specific maps (Such as a map with an orbiting planet past the borders that attracts the tide of enemies towards it as it spins) and a decent array of towers which offer multiple ways to complete any challenge.

The visuals are what let this game down and make it feel like someone's first tower defence game made in flash, at first glance. Pixel art while low resolution can be hard to master, having the visuals of a game like FTL would make this game look incredible.

reviewText:
Because of this game Steam is convinced that I like Tower Defence games...
I don't, I just like Creeper World series, that's it.
In Creeper World games, you set up energy collection grid and use collected energy to beat back titular creeper, the blue, oozing fluid whose behaviour (according to extras from CW1) is described by modified heat transfer equations. Every building and weapon costs energy to build, and most cost energy to maintain, forcing you to constantly expand to new areas to build new collectors/reactors to beat creeper back by few tiles more until you can escape (CW1) or kill it for good (CW2/CW3)

That's it. But the way Creeper interacts with shape of the map means that there's a lot of strategy involved: where do you set up a defence? Can you cover the valley with collectors AND fortify it before creeper floods it? Do you go for tight grid of expensive but efficient and easily defensible reactors or for wide and redundant but hard to defend net of collectors? What combination of weapons will you use? How many blasters? Mortars? Sprayers? Maybe use Bombers, Strafers and Cargo planes to open another front on top of the hill instead of fighting uphill? How do you handle valley and mountain ranges?

Not to mention player-made maps of all sorts, including puzzles, play as creepers" and tricky maps with lots of unexpected scripting.

Bonus highlight of the game is CRPL = Creeper Reverse Polish Language
date: a built-in scripting language giving map creators total control
recommended:
even roguelike maps can be made.


I wholeheartedly recommend entire series

reviewText:
Creeper World 3 is a tower defence game. Except instead of fighting against creeps and monsters (which are also in the game but not the main element), you are up against a liquid type enemy which is a complety new experience. It goes off Creeper World 1 and adds CW2 elements and abit of new elements itself to create a great sequel. I reccomend getting 1 and 2 as well. They are an experince not worth missing.

The experience in this game is new and refreshing. Games can go from afew minutes to even a couple of hours depeding on the map you are on. Each map the creeper is different and so is the terrain. So you have to find a new way to approach it. It include many story missions as well as randomly generated and player designed missions which makes the replayablity of the game so high.

The game is great for competitve players as well as casual players. Players compete for the best score on a map and i end up replaying a single map many times in order to get a better score. Honestly this game is worth the buy due to its unique tower defence experience. If you are new to the genre and an expericed TD player i highly reccomend this game. It's a must buy.

reviewText: Fantastic Game.\nMap creation is not only fun, but it is enjoyable to watch your friends suffer as they play them.
Great and addictive game
Just started playing this game and can tell I'm going to love it. It's a unique game, easy to learn, runs great on just about any cpu I'm sure. I'd say it's totally worth the price of admission.

This game has a thrilling story with a presentation that I absolutely love in strategy games, and it reminds me in this of one of my favorite RTS games, the first StarCraft. The gradual tech and story progression with each - sometimes long, sometimes difficult - mission, adapting to and overcoming the new challenge, is just very enjoyable for me.

Now that I finished the campaign, though, I feel I have only scratched the game's surface. With all the user-created maps, and extra map packs the game provides, I am already returning for more challenges.

A criticism I'm reading in the negative reviews is how the game is the same grind all over again. Building up basic macro and defenses, and then progressing with micro as you upgrade your tech. For a game where every map is different, leaving a wide array of viable strategies and tactics to the player, I find this a very bad point. The SupCom-esque resource system, the focus on map control and relentless assault make this game very interesting, and even the initial 'always repeated' steps come in a personal flavor and depend on the map.

The graphics may look abstract and weird in the screenshots, but they quickly make sense when playing the game. The terrain layers are also very consistent. And honestly, I found a salvo of Bertha shots' dispersed Creeper very satisfying to watch. There's few things like it.

If you're interested, watch some gameplay videos or just wait for a decent sale. I got it at -90% so sales do get decent! There's little room for disappointment at that price, and maybe it will cause you yourself to write a positive review in time.

reviewText: Creeper World 3 is an absolutely brilliant game of logistics and equilibrium, where the goal is to fight a sea of fluid. Everything comes down to building networks of weapons, shields, and other devices to slowly push forward against the rising tide. Full map terraforming, a wide variety of weapons and upgrades, movable towers, artillery, shields, and aircraft are all tools at your disposal. The story campaign has a wide and clever variety of mission types and goals, and an interesting big idea" sci-fi story line reminiscent of Arther C. Clarke is the icing on the cake here. The random mission generator

recommended: and sizable community map selection ensure you'll never run out of new challenges. A generally slow pace

reviewText:
This is the most addictive tower defense mechanic I have ever found. My only criticism would be that the custom maps are a bit limited in size, but then I understand the need to keep performance stable on older platforms. Especially when using UNITY 3D with C#.

I know its an impossible hope, but if this game were expanded in scope, via a DLC, proper expansion, or even stand alone (+ additions) I would be more than willing to pay again for it.

If you are in any way interested in the evolution of tower defense mechanics, you owe it to yourself to buy this game.

reviewText:
NOTE:

while this game might not look like very much at first, i feel like i have played enough of this game to give a few pointers if you are considering buying it or not. What i thought to be a simple game actually turned out to be quite a complex game.

it's a very good game, especcially the fact that you cann access other people's map in-game, as well as creating yourr own.
it is usually a very casual game, (except where the missions are timed) which you can take at your own pace. it's not really a tower defense game, more like a resource management/strategy game.
couple that with the fact that you get a liqud enemy and that the terrain has a extreme impact on gameplay, it makes it a very fun and different game, and can be VERY replayable, due to the Dial Map Device system, which means that you can make map as challenging (or as easy) as you like just a bit of a note: this is quite a niche game, and is not worth full price but is definately worth it if it is on sale.

EDIT:

just a bit of a side note, i have never enountered a game quite like this, so i would recommend at least watching a video before making a commitment. Although this game might seem quite 'samey' at first, there are thousands of levels to be played in various areas. And if you ever get bored of the actual game itself, there are various gamemodes that the community has made up, eg playing as the creeper.

reviewText: I love Tower Defense. I played Warcraft 3 and Starcraft 2 almost only for the Tower Defense maps. Its pretty much my favorite type of games after platformers and RPG.\n\nI say this so that you understand that when I say this is the best Tower Defense game I have ever played, it means a lot. The concept of the Creeper is just so unique and honestly really creepy and for the first time in a Tower Defense, none of my tower felt useless or overpowered. And right now, I'm 13 hours into the game and I dont think I have even done a third of the game yet. If you like Tower defense games, there is no reason to not get this game, especially for this price.

but I'll do my best:

The Creepers have emitters which slowly start filling the map with purple stuff. If this purple stuff touches one of your buildings it is destroyed. You need to destroy all the emitters to progress. Sometimes there are other objectives as well.

So you build a command center far away from the emitters. Then you start building nodes and weapons such as cannons. Each node creates lines to the nodes next to it
column17: and power flows through these lines from the command center to your weapons/cannons as well as newly placed buildings to construct them. Cannons cant link to each other
column18: but only to nodes and relay nodes. So you want to build as many nodes to create a web
column19: then a front line of weapons to hold off the onslaught
column20: slowly building more relay nodes and weapons as you manage to beat back the "purple mist".\n\nThe nodes also generate energy
column21: which you need to power your cannons and build things quickly. Build too fast
column22: and your energy goes out of balance
column23: weakening the ammo resupply to your cannons and allowing the evil purple stuff to overrun them.\n\nThere are also specialty nodes

reviewText:
Creeper World 3 is one of those funny little games that don't quite fit any established genre.

It's broadly speaking an RTS, but it doesn't really play like any other RTS on the market. It also has some tower defense elements to it, but again, it's quite different from any true" tower defense game.

Like a TD
date: it's a game about fighting a relentless enemy that keeps coming at you along predictable paths.\n\nLike a regular RTS
recommended: you build structures to harvest resources
hoursPlayed: and your towers can move around (this is very important on many levels) once they're built.\n\nYour enemy is a liquid with no ability to react to your activities. It simply spreads from emitters and flows downhill
voteText: forming pools that eventually overflow and flood the map. There's no enemy AI worth mentioning. And it's still surprisingly challenging
helpfulPercent: because there's a lot of the stuff
votesHelpful: and your resources can be quite limited. You'll have to make careful decisions about where to build something and when because running out of power at the wrong time can cause your entire line of defense to collapse in a real hurry.\n\nIt's a very simple concept
votesTotal: with only a few types of unit
votesFunny: a very straightforward upgrade system and extremely barebones presentation...and it adds up to a highly addictive game with surprising depth once you get into the tougher maps.\n\nAll in all

reviewText:
Surprisingly good game series and it's growing in quality, complexity, polish and number of titles. It's actually real time strategy rather than tower defense -- much more dynamic and fun.

The creeper is the enemy; there are structures on the map which will produce waves of creeper, which are hazardous to your units. Some structures will launch creeper artillery into the middle of your infrastructure. You use weapons to defend yourself and push the creeper back. Towards that end, you must acquire and manage your resources. Your objective is to destroy enemy offensive structures and the score is determined by how fast you can do it.

The high variety of maps presents a unique challenge every time. You can play it safe and ensure victory at lower scores, but the real challenge comes when you strain yourself and your units to win as fast as possible.

reviewText:
There are two types of people who will play this game:

1: You are addictided to high pressure situations that last for a minute. Then add 20-60 minutes of grind as you push out from a small foothold, wrangling with an unrelenting force.

2: People who only played terran in starcraft and then only turtled.

It's a bit exhausting to play long sessions as the pressure on some maps is really high. each map has been taking me between 30-1:30 to complete as i try and unlock achievements as well.

The addidion of downloadable maps produced by other players is great and i've already played a few really fun ones. I won't be playing this for a thousand hours but there is definitely enough content in here to satisfy anyone.

reviewText:
Have you spent hours of your life on flashplayer tower defense games and wouldn't go back and change a second? Then this is the game for you. This game... has an enourmous ammount of worlds for you to conquer and will have you playing for many hours.


Pros:
Game runs well even on slower computers.
Well balanced difficult game.
Has all the feelings of a good flashplayer tower defense.

Cons:
Few towers (really for the number of worlds you can conquer you have 3 types of Towers").
No upgrades for towers.
"research" Is very limited.
Online scores mean absolutely nothing because people can cheat and all the highest scores are completed in 0:00:00 seconds. (They beat the level before they even start)

Catch this game on sell and you will get your moneys worth out of it if you like playing Tower Defenses. DO not get this game if you want to compete with high scores or are looking for a more complex/strategy based tower defense.

reviewText:
Creeper World combines strategy, resource management, and meditation.

Ok, technically you can just crank up the speed to remove some of the meditative aspects, but usually on those levels I'm too busy micromanaging my energy flow moment by moment to do that.

If you've played the other Creeper World titles you'll already be familiar with the franchise approach - the enemy is simply evil water, and you're equipped with a variety of anti-water weaponry that costs energy to use, while you seek to reach and destroy the faucets that spawn your dire nemesis.

With a reasonable single player campaign and a huge quantity of additional levels, there's plenty to keep you busy.  Level quality can vary a great deal, with some really clever ones, and some that are truly just boring, with little to warn you which will be which.

Even so, if you enjoy this sort of challenge, you'll find you have a lot of quiet moments of personal accomplishment where you puzzle out some elaborate resource management or timing issue.  The game has a lot of depth, and even once you've polished off the campaign, there is loads more playtime to be had.

Overall, good stuff.  If you enjoy strategic puzzles and resource management then this is an easy buy.

reviewText:
After having read the enthusiastic user reviews, i was sure to have a lot of fun with this game.
Some hours later, i cant exactly share this view.
The games plays always the same: Protect yourself to a degree, where the enemy (brainless creep, which just grows) isnt able to get in your base, then destroy him step by step. I really am missing some personality, some intelligent behavior, like f.e. in Ai War.

Dont get me wrong, its not a bad game. But it is not a great game as well, but just another turret offense/defense game, which additionaly suffers under terrible graphics and a bad interface.

I seriously cannot recommend it for the price of 15$, regarding what (great) games you get for that amount.

Still, if you can live with the terrible presentation, and regarding the playtime you will have with this game, easily a couple of dozens of hours, just to finish the campaign, and after that, dozens of user-made content awaits, i can recommend this game, if you find it on sale...

reviewText: So basically, it's an RTS with a twist - the enemy is (mainly) some toxic slime and you need to get rid of whatever is spewing it out. There's a fluid mechanism that makes it possible for the slime to build up and spread out, which is kind of neat (e.g. if you're on top of a hill, the slime will take longer to reach you and it flows into cracks and valleys first).\n\nSo, the one player campaign begins nicely enough, you get introduced to units and game mechanics. The story is also interesting (and is mainly what kept me playing). However, it seems that on every mission there is always something new; a new unit or building you need to take into consideration that does one special thing which you need to take out some specific enemies. They're not exciting or add much to your strategy, except to kill unit X you need unit Y". Which doesn't give you much choice of an attack strategy at all
date: except to build whatever is required to make it through the level.\n\nAnd this is where the game fails the most - every level is a grind. You quickly set up your defense perimeter
hoursPlayed: it's slowly building up an attack force and inch by inch moving away enough slime to get to an "emitter"
helpfulPercent: and do the same for any other stuff you need to destroy. You know you'll make it
votesHelpful: it just takes time and there aren't many surprises.\n\nSo

reviewText:
This is a weird little entry from out of nowhere, but it's pretty fun to play with.

At it's core it's a tower defense, but it's got a real bend to it. Instead of fighting discrete units you're battling an all-consuming goo that spreads rapidly across whole planets. As you can imagine, you're going to need quite a bit of firepower and miscellaneous technology to win.

A refreshing take on the genre that avoids being the same as its peers enough that it's definitely worth picking up.

reviewText:
tl;dr: I paid 2 euros for it. Got my money's worth but not much more than that.

One of the more innovative takes on the tower defense genre, but not without its flaws.

There are no waves, just the relentless Creeper that keeps flooding the levels at a more or less steady rate. Meanwhile, the player builds all manner of defenses and the infrastructure to support it. It becomes a tug-of-ware between how much creeper is created and the player's ability to destroy it. Due to this mechanic, the hard part is usually the beginning, the containment of the creeper. Once that's done, the player would begin building more and more weapons to turn the tide in his favor. It gets a bit redundant, but luckily the devs have spiced things up a little with creative level design.

But that's just one way of playing the game. The other is to rush everything in minutes and ignore most of the depth the game has to offer. The worst part is that the tactic for rushing is pretty much always the same.

Having spent hours defeating single levels with the first method, I feel kind of cheated. I like the base building aspect in games, because it's rewarding to see the tide turn in your favor. But why would you do that if you can negate the tide before it rises up?
voteText: 3 of 15 people (20%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you want it, you've already got it, beat it and got the T-Shirt

For those of you currently unsure of Knuckle Cracker's newest escapade: A resounding 'meh'.

I absolutely suck balls at RTS's, not sure why, I just do. While there is some innovation in Arc Eternal (as with all formulaic games like it), it's mostly the same as before, both a blessing and a curse.

While the gameplay is fine, it's how it plays that I don't like. Arc Eternal is constant grindfest through the levels, all the same. Get collectors, build turrets, stabilize, then branch out. It's a slow, slow game out there, and that's going to make it or break it for you. While others may relish in it, I can't. Everything is so painfully slow and repetitive, after the initial hour or so of 'Yes! New creeper world!', it became possibly my worst gaming experience, after possibly the end of HL2: Episode 2 and Deus Ex: Human Revolution.

For extra salt in the wound, if you overextend by a ♥♥♥♥ing millimeter, the game cuts your ♥♥♥♥ing hand off, your last 30 mins of work explodes in purple creeper, and I almost screamed with rage. For that price tag? No way, just go play one of the free ones online or something.

reviewText:
Creeper World 3 is a great game if you don't mind playing only single-player, which I think is a tough sell for modern day RTS games (or even tower defense, if you wanna classify it in that bin). It is certainly an interesting concept that works and there is alot of game to be had here, complete with online leaderboards to compete with friends/the world for best level-completion times. While I enjoyed my time in Creeper World 3, I don't think I will  ever get my full moneys worth of fun.

The goal is to build and power a multitude of units to combat the creep (akin to the creep in StarCraft). The main mechanic is based off of various geographic levels, or topography, where the creep gradually covers the entire surface of the playing map - or you fight it off and kill it at the source. That is the main enemy.

Pros:
+Really fresh concept that works well
+Tons of replayability and truckloads of units to build and strategies to master
+Great value for the price - that is if you don't mind playing a single player RTS for hours on end
+It is quite fun

Cons:
-Leaderboards are not enough for me
-Having a relatively non-mobile enemy for every map can get dull (sometimes the creep has projectiles, etc., but in the end it is pretty much all the same)
-Interface needs worth, in example it would have been nice to have mouse-over hotkey help, etc.
-Graphics feel dated

I can understand why this is one of the top rated RTS games on Steam, but and the end of the day, I need a bit more out of an RTS for any kind of sticking power. I think the enemy needs more complexity.

Especially when it takes 35 minutes per try. (And no, there is no difficulty setting to make the game easier.)

If you want to know more about the game just search for creeper world on the web and try the free Flash versions. I totally recommend them.

Edit: to make things clearer: this Farbor level forces upon you a completely different play style than ALL levels of ALL the previous games in the series as well as this one, and it is NOT fun at all. It is also much more difficult than the other levels.

It took me almost one year to finally manage to beat Farbor and get to the final level which requires you to go watch a let’s play on youtube to know what the ♥♥♥♥ you must do to win. Stupid, stupid, stupid.

Also something I didn’t say originaly is that the dialogue/story in this game is a PAIN. You’re being thrown a completely stupid long story with weird and useless names that make no sense, it’s very hard to follow it, but you HAVE to read it because some important gameplay information is sometimes hidden inside the text. Seriously it sucks. Don’t buy this game.

I whole-heartedly recommend this game. Fair warning: you will become addicted to it, and rack up 20 hours playing it in a  single week. I've played it over 10 hours in two *days*.

The trailer, pictures, and even description on CW3's store page fail to do the game justice. It's RTS only in that you can place and move units while the timer is running. It's TD only in that your units only fire while sitting still, and half of your units can't move once placed. Allow me to paint you a different picture of this game. The creeper is like water that bubbles up from the ground, and you can't touch the water...because you're a cat with a lot of really cool turrets. Each of your turrets does something different. Half of your turrets aren't offensive devices; they're used to set up the infrastructure of your base, collecting resources, etc. Your energy recharges continuously, but your base can output more energy than it collects, and will eventually reach equillibrium with your input. When you start to net energy income, do you build more energy collectors, or new weapons? Eventually, you can terraform the map at large energy output, but you don't need the terraformers on constantly. Want a turret at a different location to combat the creeper? Your offensive turrets can fly. to new locations, but if your infrastructure hasn't caught up to the front, their ammo stores will drain rapidly.

Each map is essentially a series of multi-step problems that can be solved in a variety of ways, especially as you unlock more turrets. Early in the game, it's pretty obvious what tactics the map maker had in mind, promarily because you haven't yet uinlocked all of the turrets. But not even half-way through the initial campaign, you come to understand the myriad paths you can take to solve each particular step of a problem. Terraforming is a big part of this: because you can literally change the shape of the map, setting up infrastructure one way opens up different solutions down the road.

The two extremes of the spectrum of CW3 players are probably Speed Runners <----> Slow and Steady. I'm the latter right now, which is one of the reasons missions take me so long: I spend more than half the run-time with the timer paused. But you've got to be careful while paused: queue up too many turrets, and your production rapidly outpaces your income, slowing your entire system. The game doesn't punish you for being either kind of player--on most levels, your resources don't dwindle over time, so you could play a single map for hours in a trenchy-style of building one row of turrets just in front of your previous row. The game *does* punish you for not paying attention--being fast is definitely doable if your minimalistic solution has all of the right components.

CW3 is a phenomenal example of the adage: gamers prefer good mechanics to good graphics. But don't let the 2D simplistic art scheme fool you. Not only are the mechanics solid, the performance stellar, but the interface is also straight-forward, and the controls seem pretty intuitive. Left-click to select, right-click-hold to move around the map. Zoom in/out with mouse wheel. Escape to un-select or exit out of a selection. The visuals and animations tell you what you need to know, and if something isn't working like you expected, it's pretty easy to figure out why.

I wouldn't say it's a difficult game in the initial campaign, but it *is* intense regardless of your strategy. There appear to be scads of maps that the community has created that will test your skills, as will the Challenge section by the developers, *and* the custom-level editor is built right into the frakking game.

Geez...I haven't even gotten to the Titans yet....  :}

One of the best tower defenses I have ever played. Having played Creeper World and Creeper World 2, this follows the game design of the former. While the graphics may be on a lower end than that of normal games, it provides hours and hours of fantastic gameplay.

For newbies. game elements are introduced to you slowly through the storyline, all the way up to the boss map (hello Thor!). The storyline does build off CW1 and CW2, so you might be a bit lost in understanding any plot and twists. Recommendation to play the first two iterations first - they are both great games.

The game allows you to freely tab out (I'm looking at you Popcap) while remaining in play, and you are able to micromanage and rearrange your defenses when paused - a definite plus. You also get multiple save slots! The speed up buttons are also a wonderful addition - anyone that has played tower defenses will appreciate speed up buttons (1x, 2x, 3x and 4x).

Plus point is that all your games are cloud saved on Steam - no more having to rebeat the entire storymap and more when you change a new computer or accidentally clear your files! The Alpha and Prospector sector are two such additions which will provide an eternity more of gameplay once you finish storymode. The maps are heavily varied, ranging from small maps to huge maps - all of which will require different strategies. It doesn't feel like you're merely doing the same thing over and over again. And if you ever finish the abovementioned sectors (has anyone?!), there are plenty more user-made levels for you to try out.

An average map generally ranges about 15 - 25 minutes to win. It's a great game to play in between other games for a short break or while waiting for queue times.

For only SGD15.00, easily worth every single cent. 10/10

After playing the flash version of Creeper World 1 and 2 I was concerned that it will be no different in regards to quality and content. However I was really disappointed. The amount of content added is really impressive:
there are about 20 buildings the player can build in total
terraforming terrain
transporting packets via flying ships
shields that push of creep
huge artillery with unlimited shooting range
multiple map specific special buildings that can be used once connected
although main campaign has only about 25 missions, there is hundreds of other official maps available
Also the game works very well in both window and fullscreen, no problems with alt-tab, game can be paused and game speed can be adjusted up to x4.

The game itself is very simple and may get boring, but if you played flash version and you liked it, this is definitely worth £11.

reviewText: It's a bit RTS, a bit tower defense, and very very fun.\n\nFighting against what is basically a liquid is a really unique experience and the levels are, at least mostly, very well designed.
best game i have for when i cant use a mouse on my laptop
Pretty good game. Reminded me of K-D Lab's Perimeter. Second to last level is pretty tough though.

This is a great take on tower defense, with an emphasis on budgetary consumption and harvesting of resources and an enemy threat that is not unlike trying to hold back a flood.  Each level tends to be a puzzle, and the harder boards are those having the fewest number of valid solutions.  Very easy to just pick up and play, and I'm still coming back to beat levels long after finishing the main game.

You deploy your repositionable towers as you see fit, but must keep them connected to your network.  Units cut off from your network wither and die quickly.  Once you stabilize your economy (assuming you can), you transition from defense to offense to win the map.  Get good enough on the regular levels, well, by gosh, they have hard ones and then super hard ones to break your will.

They also rank your performance against others on the web, so you can see how bad you suck.  All in all, this a great strategy game.

Pros:
A unique blend of RTS and Tower Defense is an innovative twist on a tired genre.  Seriously.  I'm utterly shocked nobody else has stolen this and applied their own game to it yet.
Maps vary wildly in difficulty, taxing your ability no matter how experienced you are at the game.

Cons:
Story is short and painfully one-dimensional.
Balancing issues abound.  Since the enemy never gets any stronger, and you never stop getting stronger, surviving the first few minutes is tantamount to winning the map; Clearing emitters is a formality.
Some maps are 100% objectively impossible to beat.
Certain achievements aren't so much achievements" as "medals for playing a really really long time."

--
That said
date: the game is worth playing for no other reason than to experience the unique gameplay."

This game is listed as Tower Defense game, but its less about defense and more about pushing a wave back to its source.

Essentially your enemy isn't a monster, a beast, a beam of light... its water (this game calls it creep) and in order to stop creep from extending you have to push it back and turn off the faucet. Your enemy has no path, it goes from high to low, and can be channeled like a river or as even as a ocean.

Is it the best defense game you've never heard of... ITS NOT A DEFENSE GAME ITS AN ASSAULT GAME. Your not fighting to stay alive... your fighting to stop the expansion of your opponent any means necesary.

Story is ok... its deep and enriching but if you want to ignore it you probably will.
Gameplay is complicated, yet simple... just watch out for Farbor, if your a slow player you will not finish farbor
Music is repetitive and generic... its like 4 tracks on autoplay. The sounds are meh
Replayability? Do you like to play for time, play lots of maps, creator is very deep...

It's a very interesting take on the tower defense genre, while still possibly being considered an RTS I suppose. Really creative way of thinking strategically. There are sooo many maps to play, that you'll never get bored (if you enjoy the concept). It's not a graphics heavy type of game, or immersive, or anything like that. It's a basic strategy game, with the interesting addition of allowing you to make maps, and play other people's maps. I really love the concept behind the game, and after playing hundreds of tower defense tyle games (they're my favorite type of flash game) I can say that this style is one of the most unique I've seen, allows for more creativity in your set up, and also requires more problem solving than most. It's a great mixture of RTS and tower defense.\n\nMy only problem is that that game has a tendency of crashing when I try to open it up, but once it's open it runs totally fine.

Ignore Creeper World 2, as the game style changed dramatically for that version.  If you enjoy the game play of the online Flash versions, you will enjoy this game.  I know I did.

reviewText: This game has so much depth, so many maps and challenges and twists on familiar gameplay, plus map generators and game-modes I haven't even unlocked yet. Well worth the money for sure. I might not have a huge amount of playtime clocked on Steam, but I played the original through many, MANY hours of class time and CW3:AE is everything that was great about the original CW and then some more.

This game has always been a favorite of mine ever since it appeared for free as a flash game. Even when the game only had 10 levels or so, I still sunk hours into it. Now, after discovering it on Steam, I don't think I'll ever play a different game again. Apart from the shear number of levels, the level design - coupled with all the great new units - is so amazing. Every map is unique and has a different way of approaching it, and even then you're free to progress as you please. I could easily, and have, play 2 or more hours on a single map and barely even notice the time passing. If you love RTS type games, or tower defence, or any kind of strategy game, this game is for you.
A strangely fun take on tower defense. It's easy to pick up and play, but there's a lot to learn despite the apparent simplicity.

Pros:
A unique blend of RTS and Tower Defense is an innovative twist on a tired genre.  Seriously.  I'm utterly shocked nobody else has stolen this and applied their own game to it yet.
Maps vary wildly in difficulty, taxing your ability no matter how experienced you are at the game.

Cons:
Story is short and painfully one-dimensional.
Balancing issues abound.  Since the enemy never gets any stronger, and you never stop getting stronger, surviving the first few minutes is tantamount to winning the map; Clearing emitters is a formality.
Some maps are 100% objectively impossible to beat.
Certain achievements aren't so much achievements" as "medals for playing a really really long time."

--
That said
date: the game is worth playing for no other reason than to experience the unique gameplay."

Although it may look simple – the mechanics and controls certainly are – Creeper World 3 proves to be surprisingly challenging. The idea behind the game is simple: Defend your base, gain ground, and eventually destroy the creeper emitters to secure the world. I found the story to be surprisingly good, frequently introducing new units and mechanics while revealing the background of the creeper and areas you are in. The music is enjoyable as well.

I whole-heartedly recommend this game. Fair warning: you will become addicted to it, and rack up 20 hours playing it in a  single week. I've played it over 10 hours in two *days*.

The trailer, pictures, and even description on CW3's store page fail to do the game justice. It's RTS only in that you can place and move units while the timer is running. It's TD only in that your units only fire while sitting still, and half of your units can't move once placed. Allow me to paint you a different picture of this game. The creeper is like water that bubbles up from the ground, and you can't touch the water...because you're a cat with a lot of really cool turrets. Each of your turrets does something different. Half of your turrets aren't offensive devices; they're used to set up the infrastructure of your base, collecting resources, etc. Your energy recharges continuously, but your base can output more energy than it collects, and will eventually reach equillibrium with your input. When you start to net energy income, do you build more energy collectors, or new weapons? Eventually, you can terraform the map at large energy output, but you don't need the terraformers on constantly. Want a turret at a different location to combat the creeper? Your offensive turrets can fly. to new locations, but if your infrastructure hasn't caught up to the front, their ammo stores will drain rapidly.

Each map is essentially a series of multi-step problems that can be solved in a variety of ways, especially as you unlock more turrets. Early in the game, it's pretty obvious what tactics the map maker had in mind, promarily because you haven't yet uinlocked all of the turrets. But not even half-way through the initial campaign, you come to understand the myriad paths you can take to solve each particular step of a problem. Terraforming is a big part of this: because you can literally change the shape of the map, setting up infrastructure one way opens up different solutions down the road.

The two extremes of the spectrum of CW3 players are probably Speed Runners <----> Slow and Steady. I'm the latter right now, which is one of the reasons missions take me so long: I spend more than half the run-time with the timer paused. But you've got to be careful while paused: queue up too many turrets, and your production rapidly outpaces your income, slowing your entire system. The game doesn't punish you for being either kind of player--on most levels, your resources don't dwindle over time, so you could play a single map for hours in a trenchy-style of building one row of turrets just in front of your previous row. The game *does* punish you for not paying attention--being fast is definitely doable if your minimalistic solution has all of the right components.

CW3 is a phenomenal example of the adage: gamers prefer good mechanics to good graphics. But don't let the 2D simplistic art scheme fool you. Not only are the mechanics solid, the performance stellar, but the interface is also straight-forward, and the controls seem pretty intuitive. Left-click to select, right-click-hold to move around the map. Zoom in/out with mouse wheel. Escape to un-select or exit out of a selection. The visuals and animations tell you what you need to know, and if something isn't working like you expected, it's pretty easy to figure out why.

I wouldn't say it's a difficult game in the initial campaign, but it *is* intense regardless of your strategy. There appear to be scads of maps that the community has created that will test your skills, as will the Challenge section by the developers, *and* the custom-level editor is built right into the frakking game.

reviewText: The Flash games were amazingly fun to play, and when I bought CW3:AE, I thought it would be nothing more than an expansion of Abraxis Stimulant. I wasn't expecting many new features, and not many more were added, but this was fine. What CW3:AE did add, however, was an incredibly entertaining campaign, a fully fleshed-out map editor, a fascinating overarching story, and an experience that, although relatable to Abraxis Stimulant, felt completely refreshing and fun. If you haven't played the flash games, I certainly reccomend playing those first, and playing those first certainly impacts a player's skills within the game. However, AE did an amazing job of ensuring that all players will be able to enjoy the game, reguardless of experience in the previous games.

The beautiful successor to Creep World 1, that being CW2 was much different. This game is an RTS pseudo-tower defense game in which you battle pure entropy in liquid form. The creeper is a seeping goo spawned forth from emitters as a tidal wave sort of attack, which has killing countless civilizations before you. The gameplay consists of placing down your command node and building web-networks of energy collecters, ore mines, mortars and blaster turrets that you then use to advance on the creeper, slowly pushing it back and keeping it at bay while you build a nullifier to destroy the emmiter producing it. It's challenging and addictive 11/10

I've bought and played all variants of Creeper World, and this is the best one yet.

It's very good at scratching the strategy, RTS, tower-defense itch.

However, the nature of the enemy in most levels, essentially a corrosive liquid, combined with periodic balistic strikes, means that once you have built up your initial defense, you are effectively safe and need only expand your defensive line until you eliminate enemy towers/units. (Yes, I know there are other enemy-types besides the two mentioned above, but none that show up mid-game or late-game, to create dynamic havoc in your carefully laid plans.)

There IS the concept of pre-existing barriers that corrode, giving a timed threat-release, but these are rarely employed to anything like the full potential of providing a mid-game threat. Even if they did, there is nothing that provides a late-game threat or reversal of fortunes, no increasing flood of more powerful foes, etc. There is no ramping up of the initial threat which might turn the tide if you don't deploy for it. Really, the only way to lose a game at the mid-point or toward the end is user error, like uncovering a flank with anti-missle defenses and having an attack get through to the rear. Even then, if it doesn't cut off significant supply lines, which can easily be made redundant, then the front-line may not be affected at all by the misfortune.

But then... you can download fiendish levels that are user-made to solve that problem to a degree.

8/10 (or relatively speaking, as fun and playable as any game in the Tower Defense genre available on Steam, if not more-so)

I played creeper world 1, 2, and sim a long time ago on Armorgames or Kongregate, can't remember which now...  Either way it doesn't matter, this game is great, imagine a TD game in which you can move your towers, and you must create the most efficient supply lines you can, get upgrades, manage the production and consumption of two different resources, all in real time!  There is however a pause button, which I use often, and it makes the game managable if you like to think out your moves carefully, or if you like turn based games.  The sheer amount of things you need to think about makes this game great, and it's not overwhelming because you are introduced to new features in a logical and smooth buildup, just how a good game should be.  If you think this game might be interesting, look up creeper world 1 2 and sim on the internet, they're all free, and I promise you, this game will sell itself.

The third game in the fantastic creeper world series. It takes the gameplay of the original, and builds on it; interestingly, it gives you all of your old toys pretty quickly. The anti-creeper from the sequel makes a return, and works quite well. The level design was decent, although there were times when I felt it could've used work, and I rarely found it necessary to use more than one control node, with the exception of the timed missions.

The story was the weakest part, having reduced the cast to just two members: Abraxis and his ship's AI. There's some good world building, but I think it could've been greatly expanded upon, and the twist ending was really unexpected, and felt out of place. I'm not fond of stories that retcon their own history. If you want a great story, I'd recommend playing the original, which is still the best in this regard.

I was honestly hoping for a longer experience overall, but there is replay value in the form of custom community maps (still haven't tried it yet), as well as a random map generator which need to be unlocked through the campaign. Something I'd love to see is a massive map, spanning several screens in size, with complex terrain and hidden secrets buried around the map; the only time you excavate anything in game is during the last level.

On the whole, fans of the genre will enjoy this, just don't expect any literary awards. 8/10.

I hate to say it but Creeper World 3: Arc Eternal might have ruined me for all other Tower Defense-related games TT_TT The Tower Defense genre has become rigid and formulaic over the years, the core gameplay has become ridiculously arbitrary. CW3 has re-introduced a sense of urgency to the core gameplay of the genre, in a fresh new way. Players of CW3 are only limited by their own creativity; I've barely scratch the surface of the single player campaign and I have already developed my very own unique way of strategizing and dealing with the Creeper.

The depth of the core gameplay is intelligently designed and built, and the soundtrack is beautiful and albeit repetive, fits perfectly with the non-stop strategizing action.

How will you approach the existential problem that is the Creeper? Stretch far and thin for some quick advantages, or build up a defense to nurture an unrelenting force against the ever-growing blue goop? You decide.

5/5 Thumb up and yes, yes, yes.

One of the best tower defenses I have ever played. Having played Creeper World and Creeper World 2, this follows the game design of the former. While the graphics may be on a lower end than that of normal games, it provides hours and hours of fantastic gameplay.

For newbies. game elements are introduced to you slowly through the storyline, all the way up to the boss map (hello Thor!). The storyline does build off CW1 and CW2, so you might be a bit lost in understanding any plot and twists. Recommendation to play the first two iterations first - they are both great games.

The game allows you to freely tab out (I'm looking at you Popcap) while remaining in play, and you are able to micromanage and rearrange your defenses when paused - a definite plus. You also get multiple save slots! The speed up buttons are also a wonderful addition - anyone that has played tower defenses will appreciate speed up buttons (1x, 2x, 3x and 4x).

Plus point is that all your games are cloud saved on Steam - no more having to rebeat the entire storymap and more when you change a new computer or accidentally clear your files! The Alpha and Prospector sector are two such additions which will provide an eternity more of gameplay once you finish storymode. The maps are heavily varied, ranging from small maps to huge maps - all of which will require different strategies. It doesn't feel like you're merely doing the same thing over and over again. And if you ever finish the abovementioned sectors (has anyone?!), there are plenty more user-made levels for you to try out.

An average map generally ranges about 15 - 25 minutes to win. It's a great game to play in between other games for a short break or while waiting for queue times.

For only SGD15.00, easily worth every single cent. 10/10

Don't be fooled by the simplistic graphics, if you value your time DO NOT BUY THIS GAME! This thing is more addictive than cocaine, you won't be able to stop until you finish the campaign. I played the first Creeper World a couple of years ago and soon as I saw this on Steam I knew I had to buy it.

I'm enjoying this game, but I really don't like being forced to go through the campaign (which has levels that can become quite tedious).  There's no access to some advertised features until the campaign is finished.

Okay - if the campaign is good, let it stand on its own two feet.  Don't use it as a job" the player has to work through in order to get to the features that looked interesting.

WHAT THE GAME HAS TO OFFER:

This is a subtle balancing act between building up energy and mining operations at the right pace versus building up weaponry.  What I like about this game is the subtlety.  You might be tempted to build a lot of things only to run out of energy and then nothing gets done.

There are also interesting fluid dynamics to work with/against."

This is a gem of a strategy game. It's a RTS Tower defense-esque game, this might not sound like a good idea, but it works beautifully. There are two main mechanics that I will address:

1. The Creeper. This is your enemy, it's a liquid entity that creeps forward from spawners, slowly covering more and more of the stage. You need to build towers to fight it back, and in turn advance farther along the stage yourself. Creeper would be very difficult to deal with if it didn't obey the laws of physics. Basically, in order for creeper to overflow onto a higher level of terrain, it has to have nowhere else to go on its current level. This leads to some fairly interesting placements, like a very powerful spawner at the bottom of a deep crater. There are plenty of other enemies too, runners and digitalis namely. Runners just run along digitalis and need to be destroyed with sniper towers, they can't directly destroy your towers, but can stun them long enough for creeper to overflow onto them. Digitalis is a kind of grid-like enemy that conducts creeper and prevents towers from being built, trust me, it's more difficult than it sounds.

2. The Network. This game has parallels to a tower defense game, but calling it one doesn't do it justice. The biggest conventional differences being: Towers are networked, they have to be connected to your base to function; Towers can be moved freely, even off the network, albeit with limited ammo; towers use energy, constantly.

The biggest difference as I stated is the network. You have to build collectors and relays between towers to provide pathways for the packets" of which there are three types
hoursPlayed: and totem. This means you can't just build towers in the most strategic spots right away

The third game in the fantastic creeper world series. It takes the gameplay of the original, and builds on it; interestingly, it gives you all of your old toys pretty quickly. The anti-creeper from the sequel makes a return, and works quite well. The level design was decent, although there were times when I felt it could've used work, and I rarely found it necessary to use more than one control node, with the exception of the timed missions.

The story was the weakest part, having reduced the cast to just two members: Abraxis and his ship's AI. There's some good world building, but I think it could've been greatly expanded upon, and the twist ending was really unexpected, and felt out of place. I'm not fond of stories that retcon their own history. If you want a great story, I'd recommend playing the original, which is still the best in this regard.

I was honestly hoping for a longer experience overall, but there is replay value in the form of custom community maps (still haven't tried it yet), as well as a random map generator which need to be unlocked through the campaign. Something I'd love to see is a massive map, spanning several screens in size, with complex terrain and hidden secrets buried around the map; the only time you excavate anything in game is during the last level.

On the whole, fans of the genre will enjoy this, just don't expect any literary awards. 8/10.

Creeper World 3 Arc Eternal is a fluid time strategy game,
that is a game where you can pause and even speed up the time, just like in city builder games.

Creeper World 3 focuses heavily on base building. All buldings need to be connected to a resource network and many of the buildings can be moved in a way similar to the Terran buildings in StarCraft.

The main enemy is the creeper, which is a fluid flowing out of emitters.
This fluid will flow downhill which is usually towards you.
You cannot build in creeper and it destroys your buildings if it touches them.
The maps have 10 height levels and you can build terraformers to change the terrain gradually. This gives you tons of tactical options. The simplest example would be to build yourself a high wall as protection against the creeper.
Beware that creeper levels accumulate and if you do not destroy some, it will flow over your precious walls.
You have various guns and mortars in your arsenal to destroy the creeper and you can even deploy your own anti-creeper, but this is just pushing back against the endless flow.
To stop new creeper from forming, you need to push towards the emitter and build a special building, the nullifier, and protect it until it powers up enough to destroy the emitter.

There are other interesting foes and obstacles, which I will not spoil here.
The bread and butter of the enemy is the creeper emitter.

Most of the tension for me was usually in the early game, where I needed to stave off the creeper while building my resource economy and it's often about eeking out tiny little advantages until I could stably match the creeper. After that, the aggressive phase starts.

There are dozens of interesting story missions with diverse leveldesigns where you need different strategies to win.

After beating the story missions, which took me about 30 hours!, you have a sheer endless supply of challenge maps, as well as tons of user generated maps.

Though I find that the challenge maps aren't as diverse as the story maps, so once you find your dominant strategy, they tend to play out similarly.

Creeper World 3 is also an excellent podcast game, since all relevant information is presented visually.

The game gets a clear purchase recommendation from me.
You can play the demo version beforehand, you can find that on the developer's website.

If you've played Creeper World before, know that this is an excellent sequel. If you liked it before, you'll love this.

If not, then you're also in for a treat! CW is very, very good. People compare it to tower defence, but I usually describe it as a computer network fighting a liquid. The lines you see in the screenshots are the links between your units - if a unit becomes disconnected, it won't get resupplied and will eventually become defenceless. So, keeping supply lines going is incredibly important. The other thing is that your primary enemy is a corrosive purple liquid - it has no AI whatsoever, it just flows following the terrain. (Or sometimes it moves in other ways - the more scripted maps can have it behave in stranger ways.) The third thing is that terrain is everything. Perhaps the best defence in this game is just a really high wall... until the creeper overflows it!

This is a game about attacking, not defending however. Pushing forwards, often uphill, can be very tricky because most of your units can't attack upwards, and the creeper naturally flows down on top of you. Then you have to handle beach landings, and spore towers that will dump creeper right in your base, and runners that stun your units, and then all of these at the same time, uphill, with a time limit, along with all kinds of one-off scripted challenges too!

Later in the campaign you'll unlock units that can modify the terrain (slowly) and let you build a series of stepping stones above the creeper, or build walls to protect your home, or produce helpful anti-creeper"
date: or send supply ships to bridge between islands
recommended: or try to push the creeper away with force fields
hoursPlayed: or all sorts of other cool things. The fact that it's so freeform lets you find a style that's comfortable. I'm a big fan of terrain fiddling myself.\n\nSeriously

reviewText:
One of the most fun and unique RTS/Tower defense games I've ever played. Basically, you're fighting a liquid. This liquid flows from higher elevation to lower elevation (like liquid does). There are emitters that pour this liquid out of them at specific intervals. You have several ways of corraling and destroying this liquid. Destroying thin liquid with laser turrets, deep liquid with mortars, or distant liquid with strafers. Corraling liquid with terraformers to lower or highten the terrain or shields that shove the liquid around. Or, even combinations of the two with anti-liquid that doesn't damage your towers and can destroy the bad liquid.

There are several play-modes too.

The campaign starts you off with very little unlocked and very easy missions. As it progresses, you unlock more turrets, learning what each does with the missions getting harder and harder. Eventually, you have nearly everything and the missions have reached alarming difficulty, requiring epic strategy to beat, making each mission defeated a great accomplishment and very satisfying.

Colonial Space has a huge array of player created maps given ratings for each one with varying difficulties and extreme customization for each level.

Alpha Sector is filled with misisons created by alpha testers of the game.

Tormented Space and Prospector Zone have maps randomly generated by the engine.

This game is all about strategy, and nothing to do with luck. Love it.

I may be a little biased though, I've followed this series of games since the first. Creeper World was unique and amazing. Creeper World 2 was... okay, he took some aspects of the first one and made a different type of game that wasn't as well balanced nor built. But Creeper World 3 went back to the original gameplay of the first one, and he added many things to it, balanced it out, and made it a whole lot better.
Very fun and addictive.

Pretty much the same Perimeter (http://store.steampowered.com/app/289440/) ripoff as the first game.

Yet while the only innovations in the first game was liquidity of the Creeper and packets moving through the network itself, this game also introduces Guppies (certainly copied from StarCraft II) and Anti-Creeper (first appeared in the second game of the series).

So what's the result of the formula plagiarised and refined? It's totally awesome.
Much yes. So much replay. Stories kinda O_o but whatevs, I'll go with it. Replay eternal.

This is possibly one of my favorite games in my library. I get bored with games very easily, but this is one of the few that I can spend hours in and never even notice the time. The campaign itself has hours upon hours of gameplay, not to mention the extra level packs and the hundreds upon thousands of fan-made levels. This game is well worth the price.\n\nThe Creeper World series has always drawn me back again and again and it never disappoints everytime I plant my command center and begin the battle against that awful blue goop.
Still one of the best games I ever played!

+ Map generator - even more content!
+ Map creator and user-created maps.

- Only one song for the entire game, playing on every level. It's quite long, dynamic and really great, and takes really long to get old, but after 60+ hours I wish there was more music.
- Game really has only a couple ways to challenge you - Creeper and Digitalis with Runners. Most of the challenge comes from the map itself. Some story and player maps have very diverse objectives and obstacles, so if you got bored, go to Alpha Sector or Colonial Space.
- Some maps can take you up to 2 HOURS to complete!
- If you are a completionist type of guy - good luck to you XD ! I doubt I'll ever complete any sector besides story one.

I didn't delve much into the content beyond the campaign (which is a TON) because I just really don't have the time anymore. What I can say is that for the price the game is an absolute must for anyone into challenging strategy and/or TD games. Check it out - you won't regret it!

The Creeper World franchise is one of those games that you play compulsively and get lost in. Never has a game about supply line management been so incredibly engaging.

The story's cringey at best, but the gameplay's really fun.
First play session: 8 hours. Must be a good game!\n\n11/10 would drain my life away again
If you like strategy play this game!

Allowing you to choose and even build your own maps, this is a somewhat sandbox mode TD at it's very finest.
Yes there are some timed story levels, my only complaint.

Gameplay wise, there are so many ways to approach a problem that often you'll find yourself in minecraft mode.
With terraforming, you can raise and lower terrain, and this map change dynamic can make a play totally unique.
From digging a pre-emptive pit for the creep to go into and make good use of the mortar, making a defensive wall, to even just creating the new high ground - you're going to be able to say screw it to most conventional strategies and play your own way.

Tips for simple success:
-Do not leave snipers alone, they can still be stunned/destroyed.
-Shields should be saved for advanced strategies, most of the time they're just a major power drain.
-Soak the space behind your defensive lines with anticreeper, holds it at bay long enough to salvage a screwup
-Reactors do NOT connect to other reactors - you still need nodes in clusters

The rest, wing it, you'll figure it out.
